Which database is best with NodeJS? Redis and MongoDB both are perform well in NodeJS,But my thinking is Redis is better then MongoDB what is your idea ??

Read this, know what your project requirement is and then choose the database . And database server has to work on its own , so it doesn't matter that you use it with node.js or some other backend framework or language . You just use the wrapper to use that database. 
http://kkovacs.eu/cassandra-vs-mongodb-vs-couchdb-vs-redis
Redis is just a key-value store while MongoDB is a document store. Redis is used for storing info such user sessions, tokens and MongoDB is used for storing actual user data.
That's like comparing fish to cats. Completely different ballgames.
nothing better. It's all depend on the usecase.

I will answer my own question for 1st time : * Mongo uses javascript, Redis uses Lua 
* Mongo has MapReduce 
* Mongo uses JSON, Redis a proprietary protocol 
* both are schema free 
* Redis is optimzed for performance, and its store resides in memory 
* Mongo is document based, Redis is key-value based 
and more 

As a matter of fact, you can use both MongoDB and Redis at the same time. When you have to deal with data that is best modeled as documents, store them in mongo. When you have data that's id-value, you can store in redis. 

Example: a social service with posts and comments, where comments are a lot and highly dynamic, you can store posts in mongo and comments in redis, and link the 2 parts from the application. 
Posts in mongo let you have structured collections and documents (a post linked to an author who has connections, etc.). Comments are linked to one post only, so they are ID-Comment pairs (but comment can be a composite type) 

I suggest to read the official documentation of both engines and decide on your own which one best fits with your needs.
Then why did you ask this question here, when you can go and read the official documentation??
After u guys commented i read the docs and read the diff between the two db and then concluded .. thank u all :)
for the future, please go read up on things BEFORE asking questions. in most cases, there will be no question left ;) - don´t be lazy
Nishant Sharma see this..
I like it when people ask questions. It stimulates conversation and often causes me to research my own thoughts even further.  Besides, isn't that the whole point of this page?
it is, but not if you did not even do some basic research on your own first. that´s like letting someone else use google for you.
Redis and Mongo is used for different purposes ... so know ur purpose and finalize which one to use ....
Because the question was posted, I learned something that I wasn't even looking for. But I will have it in mind when I do need it.

Andreas Teufel , so what man ? 
why do you keep stressing on one thing that is not teaching someone something. 
Pratik Sah , I appreciate you asking this question here , because groups are made to discuss . We learnt from it and its nowhere written that you should google before you come here , because sometimes we need  direct explanation to things and expect it from such groups.

i am not "stressing" anything, just stating my opinion. googling before asking questions is a pretty basic rule for every developer. you will never become a serious developer if you don´t try to solve stuff on your own before asking. it´s also easier to learn stuff if the one who asks comes here with some basic knowledge already.
but opinions are like the airforce one: everybody got one.
Ok guys, lets keep the things clean and try to keep good habits in future, both for the person asking the question and the one answering the question.

Does anybody here have interest/experience in node.js development in IOT
IOT is just a generic marketing buzzword. It still involve regular development / programming stuff.
To clarify what I mean is backend service managing signals between items other than your computer and phone

Basically the signals are just HTTP or socket connections. So really it is just a bunch of HTTP / socket clients in many physical forms connecting to Node instances. They are not really that different from desktop or mobile HTTP clients.  Generally ,just expose the service end points with Node and code the client side to consume the services. IOT is just a meaningless term to describe pervasive connectivity of different things to the internet.

Hello guys..
I'm using node.js to build small online stock market.. 

Whole concept should look like this:
Brokers will connect to stock market (using socket.io / FIX / etc..) send stock orders. 

Stock market will accept orders (add to order list) and in interval it will process order list and send results back to brokers.

Naive solution is to use socket.io and setInterval to make stock server work. 

BUT..  it is not scalable nor cool

Do you have any idea, how to make it as much scalable as it can be?
why not do it immediately?

you can't trade after each request - there can be thousand requests each second

So it is processed in intervals..

And second thing, there can be more companies to trade with. It should run matching algorithm in intervals for each company.
Try redis with socketio, this helps the application to be scalable.
redis is fine .. but I cant imagine, how to use it in this situation

Jan Jůna node.js and socket.io by themselves made for the realtime application. You don't need to worry about these scalability, or worry about thousand of requests. Interval... it's not realtime so you don't need to user node.js also, just a raw javascript is enough, don't waste the most usage from node.js.
Btw, my current project serve for about 600 requests/s with only 1 virtual machine for node.js server and the CPU usage is just 10-20%, one more dedicate server for redis(take a look at redis pub/sub, it give you a hand for making damn good realtime messaging system), if you have more Memory you can use them both in one server but not recommended for the high-available and fault tolerant!

but how it shoud look like, when I add server? Or when I use node.js cluster module.. 

I thought, that I will make several nodes that will write requests to monodb and 1 or more nodes, which will take company, read its requests, process them and write results back.

On first nodes, the will read results from DB and transfer them to brokers via socket.io

What do you think about this concept?

Jan Jůna you dont need to worry about the thousand of requests. Everything is process in a single thread in an evented way. For running matching algorithms, create Connect Middlewares so you can process a single request in a sequence of middleware chains.
sorry I don't really understand your last message Jan Jůna
Load Balance multiple Node.js instances with Nginx with sticky sessions. Just broadcast the response to brokers clients in the anonymous function on DB save events. No need to read the DB again.

Im trying to take advantage of multicore servers.. So Id like to make more node.js servers (server A with connected brokers 1,2,3 and server B with brokers 4,5,6)

Then broker 6 send SELL request for google company to server B

Broker 1 send BUY request for google to server A

And now I dont know, how to connect these 2 requests.. First thought is to make 1 central server, which will be connected to A and B and will recieve all requests for google company.

It will process matching algorithm and then give back results of trades.. 

In normal market, there can be more than hundred of thousands requests per second so I would like to benefit of more threads/servers/clusters

Have you looked at Socket.IO docs? you don't need to strongly couple your brokers with your servers its a bad practice and not scalable at all. Just code up Node.js server with BUY and SELL API that takes company name / code for argument together with other details. All these requests goes through an Nginx load balancer that distributes the requests in a sticky manner to multiple instances of node.js server in a single machine. For matching algorithm, in the route handler attach Connect Middlewares to create a process chain that will process any number of algorithms that you want for the  request sequentially.

Blizzx Dita - but I need to pair orders from all node.js servers in interval.. so even with loadbalancer it is not solution - it will just server requests to node.js servers.. but these servers must gather all requests for company and somewhere process matching algorithm.. 

Sorry.. I don't get it.. how connect middleware helps me to gather all requests to one place?

Okay I get what you are trying to do now. Let say a SELL request comes in, you need to check whether there is matching BUY in the DB first. If there is none, write the SELL request with status flag AVAILABLE. Then let say another BUY request comes in, it will find any matching SELL requests with AVAILABLE flags on. If there is none write it immediately in the DB with status flag UNMATCH. Still you just need the same instances of Nodes across the machine no need to designate specific server for specific brokers. Not sure why you need the intervals enforced? can you explain?

These "order matching" algorithms works in intervals, because they count "strike price" from all orders.. They take orders, matches them with best price and process orders.

Example how order matching works is here:
http://market.dreamware.cz/order-matching

By the way, this is diploma thesis, so I must follow common rules, how this works..

I think what you need is a service. This service will perfom queries, run algorithms and execute orders in intervals.
So you have the following setup:
1) Clients->Node Servers(BUY n SELL Placements)->DB
2) DB->Node Order Server->Clients

The display page will connect to Node Order Server using socket.io
The SELL and BUY action page will connect to Node SELL and BUY server using socket.io or they can link to all the servers in one page happily

maybe it will be faster if I join Node Servers and Node order server too.. 

and DB will be there only for logging and for case of failure

Thank you guys for your ideas..

It wont be faster since you still need to enforce the intervals. The results wont return immediately after initial request. Be careful running interval service on the same server with buy and sell placement. It might block if it is CPU bound. Good luck
Many thanks :-)

Just go for it and worry about scaling later. Think of the user experience first. No point losing sleep with regards to scale if you don't even know if you will have any users at all. Premature optimization is the root of all bieberz.

data.message: I am curious, why do you guys use Node instead of things like Symfony? Because its hip? Because you hate PHP? Because its performance ?
Why do you use symfony instead of django? Ruby on rails? Zend framework? Play framework? C#/MVC?
being able to use javascript in both client and server programming + easiness of realtime apps (socket.io). Even without node.js I wouldn't want to use PHP, I feel it's a broken language in general
Florian Margaine: I ask you
No, yes, yes
Just compare a rails app to a Symphony app and the readability of the code is 500* clearer
So you use Rails and not Node?
I like the fact that it is JS, Which is like huge benefit being able to write client and server side codes in just JS>
I for one don't like JS at all, but the fact that it's an event driven design from the ground up makes it extremely suitable for certain use case scenarios, like IO bound web services
isn't about .php, is about I/O
All of above..!

Agree with Erik regarding merits of event driven design. For the same reasons node is particulary suitable for real time applications which are becoming more and more common across all domains. Take a look at http://blog.mixu.net/2011/02/01/understanding-the-node-js-event-loop/ for a more elaborate explanation. Also there are very valid reasons to dislike php : http://me.veekun.com/blog/2012/04/09/php-a-fractal-of-bad-design/ Not that javascript doesn't have it's quirks but once you get over closures and prototypal inheritence model, it is very consistent syntactically. Also from a business owner perspective using the most popular language in existence reduces technical debt. The node core libraries are well designed and are intuitive, behave predictably and fail in ways that can be handled in a sane fashion.

Hi,"PHP is broken language in general?" What the hell you are talking about. We got multiparadigmatic language over here, if we talking about PHP, we can do OOP [ORM] with PHP, we got lot of frameworks, open source projects, free CMS also. Facebook has build on PHP. We got Drupal, Joomla or Wordpress.  Looking forward for PHP6. Okay. Server-side Javascript is fine. I like node.js,, a like that 'Google´s V8 interpret cool phenomen', but preffer PHP, because of cheap hosting, community, history, lot of developers. Okay, I see, there are 'better' languages like Python and Ruby. But, I dont think that, the PHP is the lost way.

Anyway Symfony2 is fine, did you hear about Laravel? Also interesting project.
David Myšák it's my personal preference not to use it, but I don't think I am the only one with this opinion: http://me.veekun.com/blog/2012/04/09/php-a-fractal-of-bad-design/

I don't mind PHPs design.  But having used the overbuilt symphony I'd take almost anything over it.  I liked Codeigniter OK and Yii is probably my overall favorite for rapid dev frameworks in PHP.  But even though i'm new to node I can develop higher quality stuff faster in it than those frameworks that I knew better because it is already more mature from a productivity standpoint.  The fact that it also has way better performance, is more intuitive, and has support for... basically eveyrthing is just icing.

I mean I built my own custom web crawler in like ... 3 hours.  How long would that take in symphony?  would that even make sense?  Node and it's various plugins/packages make it like a bunch of magic web development legos.

- performance test Node.JS vs PHP:
http://blog.loadimpact.com/2013/02/01/node-js-vs-php-using-load-impact-to-visualize-node-js-efficency/

- ruby on rails vs Node.JS (linkedin has reduced 27 of 30 servers when he moved to node)
http://highscalability.com/blog/2012/10/4/linkedin-moved-from-rails-to-node-27-servers-cut-and-up-to-2.html

- and it brings us much more possibilities, what we can do .. eg. realtime apps like chats, games, push notifications,.. etc

- nonblocking architecture is also nice thing

- same code in front end, back end and even database too

- and the last one.. it's cool as hell

as for bad design of php. I disagree.  It's just weird.  There are two types of languages: those people complain about, and those nobody uses.  PHP gets used for a lot for a reason: it's easy and its design scales horizontally pretty well by default.  Also, without threads you can use all the typical single-threaded design patterns easily.  It means that junior-medium programmers can be very productive.  If the worst you get is a bunch of weird syntax (that's still not TOO bad), then that's ok.

It's also purpose built for the web.  Not a lot of other languages have things like mysql_real_escape_string(), etc, that just solve a problem for you built in.  Once again - it's all about productivity.  Performance only matters AFTER you've managed to get popular.  If nobody comes to your site it doesn't matter what it's built on.

I am a php developer from structured to mvc programming. I do sites using php for my clients. When I am planning to develop my own startup, i was thinkng like, can php scale? 

I did a lot of reseach and php is not an ideal language for a scalable site. Yeah, FB is created with PHP, but they are using "hiphop" which compiles php codes to C++ code to make the site faster. 

Some of the answers are already above. Another reason is that, I have no time to learn ruby/rails or django, I already know JS, but the approach is a bit different. the new Myspace is built with Express. So i am confident that nodejs can handle sites with heavy traffic.
Why Symfony?

I do not know of a single valid reason to ever choose php besides 'I only know php' or 'we are working with php legacy code so we don't have an option'. I'd honestly love to hear one and then specifically mention something that php is better suited for than any other option.
"I want to build a site that's cheap and there are tons of free CMS/ecommerce/blog systems built on top of PHP that perfectly fit our needs and allow us to use less expensive labor"

that is exactly what erik refers to by 'we are working with php legacy code so we don't have an option'. it might be true that nodejs doesnt have those kind of mature platforms yet, but maybe it's because php is almost 20 years old
I love node.js!  I wonder what this means for Java.
who is java

like pushing a message to the client without him asking...

I think io.sockets.emit is what you're looking for. You can use it wherever you have the reference to io.sockets. Additionally if you want to emit to a specific user or users you can store the references from the the connect event by a non-local variable or create rooms (https://github.com/LearnBoost/socket.io/wiki/Rooms).

check out some basic node.js tutorials, it´s very important to know how module loading works and part of pretty much every beginners tutorial.
Why cant you use npm on the servers?
maybe he does not want to install it. not needed anyway, because you should never update directly on the live server. better to update on dev and test it, then deploy.

just avoiding too many npm module install..
if folder means just copy and paste

But using npm would make user errors alot less frequent.
Do you use any type of deploy tool? Or do you just ftp all files up?

If you use any tool, just add a 'npm install' run to the list of tasks.
rsync is good for deployment, for example. calling npm on the live server is very bad imho...what user errors are you talking about?
Yes rsync is good for deployment for using many server..for now am using ftp for deplyment

Every extra step a user have to do during deploy increases the rate of user errors.
Calling npm on live servers might be bad but is it better to sync up a couple of thousand files?
Automatisation is (if done right) a great thing, using a tool like capistrano for depolyment and set up tests to make sure that everything runs as it should, before changing the symlink to the new source folder, is, in my opinion, better than manually upload every file with a ftp client or even using rsync. The more automated something is (and ofcourse tested) the less risk of errors due to user there is.

actually, not using npm on the live server would even be less steps ;) - because you need a deployment with rsync or ftp anyway. rsync is VERY fast, that´s no problem. rsync is not really manual, of course you have to trigger the deployment manually (in every case) but then it´s 100% automated. it´s not like you build your rsync call every time you deploy, you can put it in a deploy script and stuff. rsync is pretty powerful, you know.

You set up your deploy script once, then you just run it.

Personally i dont use rsync or ftp, but git and npm, works like a charm, and as long as the new installation is done in a seperate directory and then set as current codebase its very safe, also opens up for very quick rollbacks if nessesery (as long as you dont rm the old dirs).

Anything that works, works, not gonna try to convert anyone here, hehe. But I would recommend not using FTP for this tho, it will end up making the deployment take ALOT more time than it have to! :)

it doesn't help to know about references if you don't know how the variables come into scope and where they reference to. node brings exports into scope as reference to module.exports and this is what the post is about.
if it helps someone to get a grip on references vs. values I'm happy too.

Still the simplest explanation is that module is a global object (like window in the browser) in terms of a node instance. module.exports is a sub-object and exports is a reference to module.exports. But you're right - scoping is important here, and showing how you can easily break things by swapping the build-in references can save beginners a lot of headaches :)

data.message: I know this is only partially node-related, but since front-end frameworks are so commonly paired with node, I figured this is my best shot at getting several perspectives (Stack Overflow hates open-ended questions like this). Anyway, has anyone paired Socket.io with a Javascript MV* framework, and gotten server-push working well? I am looking for a framework that would work well with atypical SPAs, as in not just basic CRUD apps (to be specific, real-time PBBGs). I have to say I have just not liked Angular so far, but it is on my list to work with more down the line. I guess the 2 main ones I am reviewing are Backbone and Ember, but am also open to more suggestions if there is something else that would meet my needs well. Both BB and Ember have Socket.io modules, but they are fairly small and I don't know how well they are supported. Thank you!

It would be a bonus if I may end up coming across professional work in the framework as well, so as nice as rAppid.js may be, for example, I probably wouldn't go that way since the experience would likely be of little benefit professionally.

have a look on polvo the compiler we use to build our sites. the compiler holds a socket.io server which is used to do live devlopment and its ready for a tweak that would allow pushing among other features.
We are already working on its new version that will expose all hooks so you will be able to do it without touching the core. Weare willing to give you an introduction if you need. search "github polvo"
Looks interesting. But is this a client-side framework? It is hard for me to tell from the README what this actually is

its a build system, you can build either client or server side. the compiler is a http server and socket server which  comes already with "live reload" for css/js/html when in dev mode.

you would just extend the server for your extra needs, like pushing code or any other thing. not saying its your ideal solution, its just an option in case you would feel comfortable working on something in your way ( just fork and go ahead )

How do u deal with foreign characters like hindu, japanese, korean, hebrew in mysql db? 

I know this can be done by adding/setting utf8_general_ci for each table u did but do i need to convert mysql compatible text format  or just insert whatever character it is to the db?

utf8_general_ci is just collation rule. It does not actually collate by language collation rules (that particular one). Content (data) is content - you shall decide how you want to be stored (encoded or not). Usually default depends on a unicode support that programming language use and obviously what mysql will understand by what you have sent.

this could help: 

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3328968/how-can-i-store-unicode-in-mysql

It's really magical.

data.message: is it really a MUST for a complex site to have an ORM like sequelize? I feel like I am more comfortable to use the plain or basic mysql method than orm.
Yes, it's a must. You will waste a lot of time on writing things that are already implemented in Sequelize. Also: security concerns. And what if you want to change DBMS?

In my humble opinion, It would depend on the direction of your project and what the immediate union current needs are.

Check this article out.
http://sigpwned.com/content/should-i-use-orm-or-not-sure
my heart is still 50/50 -______________-
DRY
well, i don't think we're here to convince you, you do whatever you want with your project, we're are just giving advice!!!

Nah, im already convinced actually. To think about it, expressjs is a webframework to make ur job faster.. while sequelize is an ORM to make ur dbms faster.so there's no point   for doing the old school way.. :3 thanks everyone :3
yup, its simply easier to use sequelize.....
aha! ORM for Node. I asked before as I was looking for some good ORM for node.

There are reasons to use raw SQL.  Some things sequelize just can't do.  But you can still run raw queries on sequelize and use the ORM for everything else.  That way if you have to refactor/change DBs you only have to deal with those few queries that don't match.

On that note, if anyone knows how to do variable x is greater than A but less than B in sequelize or do a multiple join with sequelise (where table1.var = table2.var and table2.var =table3.var) etc. I'd love to know how
It's not a must. Raw SQL is faster than ORM. ORM is convenient. I am using sequelize which also allows raw SQL.
well an ORM use raw SQL, an ORM is just a series of functions that use SQL
ORMs are for "i whant my program to be available to anyone using any db system". If you write stuff for your own db system, write a service layer with or without it.

If i can ask, so please answer my new question:

there is my first very simple app based on node, its better dont call it app, this is 3 menu that change the pages, but problem is here: when i click on the menus, the pages change fine, but the menus disappear for a moment  and then appear again when the new page load complete, i used fs module to load HTML pages content, but its seems to be slow, something is wrong there, it must not be like that, what is the problem ? why this delay happen ?
data.caption: Attachment UnavailableThis attachment may have been removed or the person who shared it may not have permission to share it with you.

data.message: you're using just fs module, and in my opinion it's not a good idea, i suggest you to use ExpressJS will help you a lot in your little application ;)

Hello Kourosh Sharifi. You are free to ask questions here, related to Node.js and Javascript. Better use Google before asking it here.

The problem with your app is that you are doing a full page reload with each click on the menu, which is leading to disappearing of menu for a short time. You need some kind of view mechanism so that your menu stays there at the top all the time, and just the body content changes when a menu is clicked. 

For that you need to look at client side libraries such as Angular, Backbone etc.
If that overwhelms you, then try Sammy.js [ http://sammyjs.org ]
Is anybody else aware of some server-side solution for partial loading of page?
don't ask to ask ...

Okay, Nice, But i used PHP file_get_contents to simulate this app with PHP and this issue not happen anymore, is this problem about fs module ? or it related to the Node ? what if i dont want to use any framework like backbone or Express ?

Its not a problem with fs module or node, its just how web apps are done. Instead of reloading the full page, just a part of page is loaded. 

And what you are trying to achieve is possible without using Node. If you are not using any frameworks, you'll be reinventing the wheel.

I just to try comparing PHP file_get_content and Node fs module, PHP file_get_content and Node fs module is no partial either, so    why this issue happen is Node fs Module but not happen in PHP ? This my question.
Your assets are not wired properly in your node app. That might be the reason.
also, why file_get_content? that´s not comparable to what you are doing in node, because it´s meant to parse external links. also, curl is better/faster than file_get_content.

slow is because apache handle your css & js in php your browser most likely cached the all your assets from your first request, other than that apache may do gzip, server side cached. in your node app you need to code to serve the file (you have not done that). manually serving static files you should at the very least use streams to pipe to response.

see how others do it http://ejohn.org/blog/node-js-stream-playground/

express.js use send to handle static files https://github.com/visionmedia/send

Would really appreciate if someone could help.

What is diffrence between request.url and url.parse.(request.url).pathname ?

req.url includes both the path and the query string while url.parse(request.url).pathname will only contain the path without the query string

Eg.

url  -  /hello/1/3/4?a=b&x=y
req.url  -  /hello/1/3/4?a=b&x=y
url.parse(req.url).pathname  -  /hello/1/3/4

i would say it is probably better to server static files, imgs etc using nginx as it is way quicker, and proxy api requests to node instances running on a separate port(s) that way you don't need to be root and run node on port 80
ghost.org and the new myspace.com are using nodejs..
I do not know if nginx is faster necessarily. I believe most benchmarks show nodejs tied if not higher, especially if clustered.
What benchmarks?

I mean, you can google it if you would like. There are results going both ways; some even say Apache wins (whaaaaat?)

So, take it with a grain of salt. I believe Ryan Dahl shows some benchmarks in his release almost 4 years ago that show them being comparable with Node having the edge (though I admit I have not watched this video in some time) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M-sc73Y-zQA
I believe it's quite common to proxy requests through nginx on production. I hear everyone do that so there must be a reason and I think performance is not the most important thing here. :)

I really meant strictly for static assets such as images. You can cache them in memory with node but its not very efficient. I have experienced this definitely, however I do not have any benchmarks. In my use case it was a difference between milliseconds and over a second. 

You could certainly use node to cache template strings; that would still be quick; but lots of large images in binary/base64 would store a minimum of the file size in memory and slow down your server from handling lighter requests.
By clustering you would get a quicker response from serving raw files, as you could have 2+ processors serving disc reads (or writes) and using streams would allow better concurrency, however the response of one file streaming to synchronous would be slower in a direct 1-to-1 comparison.

In reality there are a lot of factors involved in this and every one use-case/situation is different. It really depends on what you are trying to achieve in your project, how many visitors you expect your site/app to get, how many static assets you will be serving, the size of those assets and what hardware resources your server has and/or is available.

If it is just a small site/prototype with small to medium traffic it will really not make a huge difference.

With regards to proxying there is not much difference between putting nginx in front of node and using nginx/apache with php or ruby/python with passenger. The only difference is that with php i've not heard of people running a php server on port 80 without nginx or apache, where as with node this is easy and common.
Also I might add if you do use nginx in front of node and your node process goes down nginx can handle the response to your user more gracefully.

> I posted a status at 2:27pm / but it will be saved in New York timezone

> the site will display the post in PH timezone. that mean, the site automatically convert the NY timestamp to PH timestamp

> if I move to...let's say Italy, the site will be automatically convert it to italian timezone

> the site will detect user's  timezone using jquery on frontend side...
Save it as UTC. :-)
ive read an article from somewhere, UTC is recommended..

Save it as UTC, and then record user's time zone for each user. In this way all records can be shown calculated in each user local time. Some databases will even help you with that.

This is also highly recommended when (if, but more likely when) you hit daylight saving problems with time.

Even more mature systems have problems with DST.

So UTC it.

I have spent some time pondering of various chat scenarios and played with node sockets, and came to main conclusion here. Main considerations would be:

How that chat would look like?

There are 3 different approaches in sense of making application:
1. command line
2. desktop web based application (e.g. node+webkit)
and of course
3. web based app (runs in standard browser)

Second how this chat will work?

1. centrally connected
2. peer to peer
3. mix of above two

of course a server considerations in central model (node or something else including web and messaging).

Once the model is decided, then approach can be selected. (even then there are some doubts, for example I did came to number of discussions on the line Socket.IO or WebSockets or sockjs or ????)

Simple wish - not a simple task.

Have you tried configuring your transports? Socket.io has fallback transports, xhr-polling is what I think does what you described:

io.set('transports', [
  'websocket'
  , 'flashsocket'
  , 'htmlfile'
  , 'xhr-polling'
  , 'jsonp-polling'
]);

https://github.com/LearnBoost/Socket.IO/wiki/Configuring-Socket.IO

Arbie Samong I've tried just. but this way haven't worked OK.

I changed like this.

io.set('transports', [
    'xhr-polling'     <<< I changed the order.
  , 'websocket' <<< -
  , 'flashsocket'
  , 'htmlfile'
  , 'jsonp-polling'
  ]);

at first, browsers are connected with 'xhr-polling' OK. but that's all!
It doesn't try to connect with websocket again.
of course not, it takes the first one that is supported. try using an entry page with ajax and redirect to a page with socket, what about that? i am not sure if you can switch manually.
Andreas Teufel OK. now, I'm considering that a module for this doesn't exist. So I think I should try manually. but I'm a beginner. anyway I'll try again it you said above. thanks for advising me. :)
How about two instances? One with xhr poll configured and another with websocket. Or see if you can reconfigure after some time

Appologize to intrude, I would like to learn something here too ;) So

It looks to me that webSockets (that would be W3C spec) is not ready yet (and will not be ready for some time). Second if that is not ready there is choice, so far I understand there is quite talked about SocketIO but I also stepped onto Sockjs that would be intermediate work for Web sockets. Also unlike PUSH to client method (as main driver for socketio and sockjs), we have PULL from server method (ajax) + security limitations on a browser side.

Now, I see sockjs is already some 2 years old, while socketio is still under some debate. Where do we stand today with w3c and these two? Is it worth jumping in now? And which one to choose? (maybe this shall be separate topic)

iirc socket.io now takes care of that automagically . PS network delay will take time (In no real world scernario websocket can be slower then xhr-comet), you can rather send the first packet as json [something like sails.js] and then wait till u establish connection using websockets.

how do I configure a node.js server so that its accessible in the entire local area network, not just on my local machine?
tried it but unfortunately no luck...any other configuration that might work? or maybe its just the lan network that blocks it

server.listen(3000, '127.0.0.1') should work. If it doesn't, then it might be your firewall or your router blocking port 3000.
enabled 'Evented I/O for V8 Javascript' in my firewall but still not accessible...must be the college lan settings...any way to check?
nope... if you bind listening to an 127.0.0.1 (or your IP number) this is listening on a localhost connections. If you wish to listen to the world general advice is to listen to 0.0.0.0 - try.
thanks it worked.!

Actually to be accurate this shall be the logic:

127.0.0.1/localhost - you bind your listening to localhost only (this is good protection if your system shall work on  1 cpu-box and internally e.g. your web server talks to your database but you do not want that someone else outside make connection to the database meaning out of local cpu-box, your database will listen to localhost and web server to world)

your ip - you listen to the world but only on the interface that has that IP address. This is fine solution only caveats there would be: if you have more than one interface, other interfaces are not listened to, second, if you move your code to another cpu-box with another IP you need to change the code, and of course IP that changes breaks your web application (eg DHCP).

listening to 0.0.0.0 says: listen to all local interfaces all IP - basically listen to all incoming traffic.

Maybe you shall read some networking books there is plenty of documentation on IP protocols on the net.

so if i create 2 servers then using my ip in the listen() would work for only 1? 0.0.0.0 looks a better option then...one more thing-are there any security issues with this method?(i.e. can i get hacked? :P)

Sorry but I did not understand your question (first part).

Second part: listening to 0.0.0.0 is nothing to do with being vulnerable to hacking. Your app is weak point for hacking not interface you are listening to. Listening to 0.0.0.0 simply says - listen to all incoming traffic on your cpu-box (PC) - this is simply socket specification (assumed network mask is also 0.0.0.0)

If you wish to make app that works only in intranet you'd need to filter out some traffic - ie detect corresponding IP and allow/refuse connection (this is why node is not the same as web servers). In apache web server you can configure to listen only to a set of external IP's (eg 192.168.0.0/255.255.255.0 apache will respond only to other PCs with IP's 192.168.0.0 - 192.168.0.255 but will not listen/will refuse connection for example from 192.168.1.x) in node you have to write that filter for yourself (sorry no shortcuts or easy solutions)

To be honest I never tried to experiment with node sockets, maybe it is possible to specify IP/netmask in some way. If it is possible then you can limit listening to allowed set of IP's, but generally speaking allow/deny comes on top of socket (i.e. it is later logical security layer built in your application)

http://nodejs.org/api/net.html#net_class_net_server

server.listen(port, [host], [backlog], [callback])#
Begin accepting connections on the specified port and host. If the host is omitted, the server will accept connections directed to any IPv4 address (INADDR_ANY). A port value of zero will assign a random port.
------

this above is section from node.js reference, note situation that you can omit 'host' in that case you listen INADDR_ANY this is the same as saying server.listen(port,'0.0.0.0') with 0's you are just being specific.

now I understand why there is so much talk about node socket. There are but very few examples. Its worth writing an article explaining what happens in some basic communication, when and how. I tried to write a simple unix pipe type of socket and have run into a number of doubts.

On the other hand, Node sockets are actually very simple socket implementation no big and complicated stuff.

Hi there.. My tasks run and the files exists in this folder that i am reading from..
But why dont they get into the destination.. thanks..
um... dafuq is regexp? You do know that ECMAScript comes with regexp matchin in native String objects right? https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt-contrib-copy can get you further here I think

aah. !!!.. I could do that but this code in another large plugin.. i just made up a small one out of it to test it independently.. 
btw why doesnt it get piped to destination is what I am concerened..!!
btw u cant rename files using that plugin, Stefan Staudenmeyer..

First of all, piping from a source to a destination file is exactly the same as copying.

Then, piping is an asynchronous process. Your node process probably quits before the piping has finished.

Grunt tasks are by defaults synchronious, if you want an async task to run (piping is async), you need to call this.async() inside the task, which gets you a callback function you can use to notify Grunt the task is done.

add something like this at the end:
dest.on("end",this.async());

note that this will, obviously, only work for a single file, you'll need to do more complicated async logic to support multiple file pipes  (you'll need to join the async threads and then call the this.async() method on the last async thread, try using the npm module async)

Somewhere in end of 90ties and beg of 2000 there was a project that sounded interesting yet to my knowing it never picked up after that initial spin. Back to original subject This node os i something that could be very small yet capable, so Pi would be possible target (do not know how you'd run it on arduino because of its lack of multitasking). For sure I would not run node os on a PC unless it is some small transportable pc with limited resourses.

Using full PC to run home automation or robot is a bit of an overkill for me.

Chrome OS is in my view amiss. However if they just added a local web server and a database to that machine it could be full platform that you could do interesting stuff offline and online. Node has relatively small runtime (so it may be multiplied), also I guess it shall have some C compiler otherwise it would be tricky to add significant library functionality. nodejs can be vulnerable to an injection of javascript?
SuperLike! Very Valuable point for contemplation.
If you just eval "untrusted" json then this is a vector of attack.
eval is evil. just saying.
so how to make ur node app secured?
use brain instead of eval
experience and common sense?, i agree with Ljubisa Gavrilovic
Ljubisa Gavrilovic why would someone want to eval JSON when it can be parsed? or both are same?

My early post was just loud thinking. 
And no - they are not the same (eval & parsing)

JSON like structure is chosen because it directly translates to data facilities (structures) of javascript language and shall be possible to be eval-ed to internal values. In fact in early days of javascript prior to appearance of JSON it was quite common to use pieces of code as data structure and communicate it over the net and someone may use this technique today as very convenient and powerful. You'd simply eval such code (this is possible because javascript is interpreted language)

AFAIK (not in much detail) there was number of protocols that could pass a functions (methods) together with the data. Today we are discouraged to do that because of potential security attack vectors. But in early days of OO idea of exchanging objects over the net (not only data but also a functionality) was very strong only to be discovered later that this is not very wise approach to do if you do not control whole system. BUT it is still very powerful concept of computing. 

Think of it as callback functions that are not in code but sent over internet. There is a lot of possible uses for such approach.

In a way I miss not having passing 'methods' in JSON but that can be implemented as for example a set of library functions.

Parsing is different technique and applies to structured data processing (as textual data). Eval is equivalent to execution. These are two completely different approaches to processing the data.
I often wander if JSON parsers are actually secure.

just a bit more on eval (came to my mind later when thinking of parsers). If you do eval you are reusing built-in javascript language parser instead of using JSON parser (that may be implemented in js code or as binary). I could bet that eval is much faster in parsing.

data.message:
The process of "zipping" a file refers to putting it into an archive format such as "ZIP." This compresses the file, making it smaller. You can compress several files into a single ZIP archive, making them easier to store and transfer over email as the files are smaller, and they can be moved by just moving that one ZIP file.

To know more on how you can zip files in node.js, read our blog:

Honestly you will probably have to learn SQL for school, so you could get a jump on that. But schedule in some time to also get to know MongoDB. It won't take long to learn since it is so much more simple than SQL. Mongo is also a great fit for node.
if you want to take it serious, you will have to learn both.
i will learn both ,but i want to ask that is it necessary to first learn SQL ?
thanks Tim Crouch
mongo ftw

I think you should learn first SQL then when you have learned the concepts of relational databases, you could learn noSQL databases such as mongoDB. As others told you, it wont take to much time to learn mongodb.
Mongodb has different approach to relational databases.
You might also want to take a look at this site:
https://class.coursera.org/db 
and last: https://education.mongodb.com/ 
for me the best place to learn mongoDB.
thankyou Carlos Carcamo :)

Learn SQL first, no doubt. I hate to say it, but if you learn Mongo first, you will be screaming in your head "Why is all of this complication needed?!" when learning SQL. Plus, even though Mongo is NoSQL, having a good understanding of the kinds of things you may need to query in SQL will actually help you design better Mongo databases. It is also doubtful your school will teach Mongo, as most universities have not created a curriculum for NoSQL, so learn first what will directly help you in school. But follow it up with Mongo. It is awesome!
before you learn sql or nosql, learn about mathematical sets. All databases emanate from set mathematics. Once you understand sets you will understand sql select/join and nosql map/reduce.

Use an ORM....know SQL basics, but no need to master it unless u want to become a DBA.

In nodejs... At least for basic uses, LOTS are similar when u look at mongoose vs sequelize (both ORMs. For nosql and SQL)
Different story if ur actually someone that wants to join in orm development....but for most cases its quite fine to just use orm

i couldn't say which is better, but I got fluent in mysql and php before even touching node.  I've used nosql a bit and it doesn't feel as neat at mysql, but it is more restrictive.  i'd say just do 2 projects and use one on each, then decide for yourself.
SQL first. When there are problems you cannot solve with SQL, then you go NoSQL.

Hello. I am still learning Express and I have a question. How do u clean the POST data from the form? like removing html tags, converting characters to mysql-compatible data, and so on...

you could try to use some middleware for that, like:

app.use(express.bodyParser());

and then in your handler, use req.body object (here are some more details on that http://expressjs.com/api.html#req.body)

Now, assuming you send ?foo=bar, you would access that like this: req.body.foo

Cheers! :D
app.use(express.bodyParser()); <---this line where i always see that i dont even know what the heck this was XD , does the cleaning job?
ok,ill read that.. :D multumesc! :D
I see. :3 #noted :D

Actually sending ?foo=bar is a query parameter.

If your route is registered as app.post('/users/:name') and you make a POST request with data { "age": 23 } to this url: /users/john?nickname=johnny

You get:
req.params.name => "john"
req.body.age => 23
req.query.nickname => "johnny"

I'm pretty sure that if you don't have the content-type:application/json setup in the right place, age will not be available.
Anyway, the bodyParser middleware knows how to abstract data (name/ value pairs, JSON body and multipart) and it all ends up in req.body.

Leandro Ostera: what you've written is a combination of named placeholders, GET parameters (or query parameter as you've called it) and a JSON body.

Leandro Ostera ST3 - not an option, maybe at some time when I go up with OS, but seeing what apple did with new OSes after 10.6 I am a bit reluctant to move (and loose some significant functionality while gaining questionable usability gadgets) Eventually I'd need to move, but not as yet.

You seem to be quite an opinionated guy.

A part of me really wants to understand why you open a modern editor in an old operating system and expect it to work like a charm. It's like trying to run Node on Windows. At the end, it's far better to fire up a VM with a decent UNIX-like.

The other part of me really wants to punch you in the face for not catching up. :)

I am opinionated :) yes. I figured that during answering to you, opinions come from experience.... (especially bad experience)

You see I like pick my tools slowly and pick them because they are good, not because they are cool. My tools are working and would not give up in critical times. 

I love to see new things. I like cool things. But more than often I would go back to old tool if it is more stable and trustworthy. But I will support new things if they are good. New OSXes are not (going too much to the IOS way - that is bad Apple move)

Whatever i do i try to do on more than one platform and environment and, yes, i use node on OSX and windows. Blasphemy blasphemy ;) Herecy :) :)

Now, there is something about sublime, it needs some consolidation - conceptual. It is likable, cool, hackery but not yet good, at least not for me.

At the end of the day node is hackery too. It is far from good tool yet. But it is ehm, innovative and promising. Has good vibe. Its javascript renaissance. Hope it stays that way (i am too long in software development - so long that I have seen languages crazes come and go) Javascript deserved some push - node was that push. I welcome it.

serverside javascript is not new thing (it was present in original netscape server (approx mid 90ties) and you could write server and client side in the same HTML) - unfortunately netscape server was never popular because it was too expensive.

Application side javascript is not new thing either there was MicrosoftScriptingHost with JScript (which was at its time extremely good implementation). But Microsoft did not put it because they wanted to make it good, but because it was fighting with Netscape at the time.

Node come from people in the way - hey let's see if this idea can work. I love node because it is brave idea. Brave ideas deserve support.

It is somewhat unclear to me how it will go with mixture of approaches sunc/async but being brave it will show us what we can understand of frontier and pioneer approaches.

Just one more thing - Javascript is very old language in terms of computer history. Why you are using old language? :) (food for thought)

Also one suggestion:

If you want a young language check Go (http://golang.org/). That's modern language!!! :) With built-in concurrency on top of all other innovations.
Błażej Ka if this was comment on my above reasoning I agree my writing is off topic. Fathi Tarek looks for code editor for a beginner.... (though not specify which OS he uses... assumed.. ) :)
Hi, I want to ask about how to write some text to file in Node.JS ? what i need to add a library/module with NPM or using default Node.JS library/module ?. Many thank
buddy you have to use File System API of nodejs, http://nodejs.org/api/fs.html see this documentation. it provides both sync and async features.

Do you design before programming?

I've just programed so far without designing, I'm always going through difficulty for maintenance.

Is there much difference I did or not?
Should I design first?

and is it OK to use mind-map tool for it?
Is always good to make a plan. It will be easier to maintain and reuse code for other projects. Less code repeated, the less chance of errors.
yes you should design first. even if it´s just on paper. and check out TDD (test driven development) too.
Of course, you should frigging design first! Even if it just thinking for an hour and drawing a picture on a napkin, design is essential.
David Gironella Casademont I can be sure by your favor. Thanks to answer for me. :)
Andreas Teufel ok! I'll do it from now on. I'll spend for designing even more much time. Thanks :)
David Tomlinson I haven't thought that it's not very important, but now I realized the importance of it. Thanks for your advice. :)
using mind-map tool can be useful. Design phase is very important, don't skip preparing user stories and design. Jumping into development without design isn't good thing to do.
Md Rezaur Rahman Ok. So far I've felt like going somewhere without the map for my destination. I didn't know what to do. So, I'll do it from on now. Thanks :)
btw.. is there any design tool like enterprise architect for node.js or JS? Something, what will generate basic structure of application, or do you write your code from scratch?
express ;) - or yeoman

ok.. same question - is there some graphic tool to generate express sculpture? :-P 

Something what will take UML and generate code..
Woah, UML? Get outta here.
nope, nothing like this out there as far as i know.
Jan Jůna Yeoman will help you to generate a basic working application.
thanks.. :-)
Learn and use Object Oriented Analysis and Modeling...  Write use cases and draw atleast class diagrams first.. Model your system..  It is essential...

That's like the worst advice to give someone. And unless you work in huge (millions of lines of code) Java applications, it's mostly useless to sit down and do all your UML homework.

Keep it simple. Go agile. Let the architecture emerge from your application and some guidelines. And ffs keep your inheritance as shallow as possible. Easier to get, easier to explain, easier to maintain.
A little amount of common sense and a pen and paper should do the job.

Design but do not over-design. Design where you need a design not everywhere. If you plan large maybe you shall design or better you may be better not going large. If you over-design you may be inflexibile.

See if you can conceptualize idea, then make a version. Try to be realistic. Almost always once you start using it you realize that we are rarely able to forecast real need in advance thus do not expect to guess everything in your design. I loved book from 37signals - these people really hit a nail.

In fact some really simple things became really large. Use twitter for example. In essence that is insanely conceptually simple system.
OK! I really realized that a design is very important. Thanks to your help!

Please help me write the solution for this problem from "Learnyounode" Tutorial .

This is the problem statement :

This problem is the same as the previous problem (HTTP COLLECT) in
that you need to use `http.get()`. However, this time you will be
provided with three URLs as the first three command-line arguments.

You must collect the complete content provided to you by each of the
URLs and print it to the console (stdout). You don't need to print out
the length, just the data as a String; one line per URL. The catch is
that you must print them out in the same order as the URLs are
provided to you as command-line arguments.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
HINTS:

Don't expect these three servers to play nicely! They are not going to
give you complete responses in the order you hope, so you can't
naively just print the output as you get it because they will be out
of order.

You will need to queue the results and keep track of how many of the
URLs have returned their entire contents. Only once you have them all,
you can print the data to the console.

Counting callbacks is one of the fundamental ways of managing async in
Node. Rather than doing it yourself, you may find it more convenient
to rely on a third-party library such as http://npm.im/async or
http://npm.im/after. But for this exercise, try and do it without any
external helper library.

The Previous problem

Write a program that performs an HTTP GET request to a URL provided to
you as the first command-line argument. Collect all data from the
server (not just the first "data" event) and then write two lines to
the console (stdout).

The first line you write should just be an integer representing the
number of characters received from the server and the second line
should contain the complete String of characters sent by the server.

Instally locally :npm install express

You have two options.

1. Download Linux and install Node from repos, binaries, or source. Then install express using npm.

2. Open Internet Explorer, order a Mac, install using the installer or homebrew. Then install express using npm.

"Error: Can't set headers after they are sent."

How can I fix this error?

That happens if you try to set a HTTP response header, even though you already ended the response. Like this: https://gist.github.com/saschagehlich/44f7b2c0b58dfd53e2f1
In your case the problem is in line 42. You are ending the response, even though the SQL query might not be done yet. Remove that line and it should work.

Heroku is kind of slow if you go with a free plan. Try a VPS at first. Personally, I've used http://www.intovps.com/ , and it was very good (both services and support), and now I'm using http://digitalocean.com/ . DigitalOcean is cloud-based, and it's a good service. Both of these have a starter $5 plan, which for a single (or couple) of websites is more than enough ;)

The last two years I've been making a kind of programming competition platform called 'Escape from /dev/null' in node.js and client-side Dojo.

It's a system that has two parts; first it's a kind of web-based board-game where teams can choose to take on certain programming 'quests'. The second part is a live web-based API that the programming quests are targeting.

The web-based APIs are of different scenarios, one is a space survival and the other (current) is a multi-user rogue-like game where teams can (as part of the programming competition) create characters, solve problems and so forth.

https://www.facebook.com/EscapeFromdevnull?bookmark_t=page

I've coding Java for about seven years prior to learning JS (beginning in 2005) and I can easily say that I wouldn't have been able to do 1/10 of the system with a legacy lagnauge. very, very happy with node.js

What's the craziest system other people have cooked up with node.js?
data.name: Escape from /dev/null
data.description: Escape from /dev/null is a series of programming competitions, where each team solve small (but increasingly complicated) programming challenges to move ahead on a communal game-board.

Hi,  can nodeJS be used to build high performance, scalable web applications? What about nodejs frameworks? Do we have good mvc framework for nodejs? Given a choice among CodeIgniter(php framework)  , django,  ruby on rails,  grails and nodejs  which would be the best choice to build a scalable web application?  Why?

The most common approach that people take when building a Node app, is to use Node at the back-end for providing a REST API, talking to the database or third-party services and then use a client side MV* framework such as Backbone, Angular etc. to consume that API. Most of the application logic is wired at client side and rendering is also done at the client side. And the simple reason for using Node is to have a full JavaScript stack.

Depends on what ur trying to build. But PayPal and LinkedIn has already switched over.
Primary reason is language is same for both front and back end.

Express.js is currently in lead (by far) as for framework.

Have fun!

No one  can't recommend or explain something that we doesn't know, i mean, we dont know the goal of  your app to recommend  something to you now, but if this  is your first time with node.js you should start with express.js.

If scaling, concurrency, and lightning-fast backend is your primary concern, have a look at Google's language, Go (http://golang.org/). Most people like nodejs for concurrency and consistency, and because they already know Javascript.
i would not start directly with express btw. that´s like starting with jquery before learning javascript. write your own little server before using one of those frameworks.

Introduction to Elasticsearch and Beyond:
Elasticsearch is fantastic at providing approximate answers from data, such as scoring the results by quality. While elasticsearch can perform exact matching and statistical calculations, its primary task of search is an inherently approximate task. Finding approximate answers is a property that separates elasticsearch from more traditional databases. Find out more: http://www.slideshare.net/Intelligrape/intro-to-elasticsearch-and-beyond
data.name: Intro to Elasticsearch and beyond
data.caption: www.slideshare.net
data.description: Elasticsearch is a tool for querying written words. It can perform some other nifty tasks, but at its core it’s made for wading through text, returning text s

data.message: Help me.. I want to pass some parameter to a handler of another file, when app.get("/", handler) is called. How should i do that..? i don want use global variable because of reuse rule... Can i do this  without global variable?
illustration!  file1.js: exports.handler1 = function(param){...} , file2.js: var file1= require('/file1'); app.get('/', file1.handler(myparam));   hope it helps
Paap SaamBâ Joop the handler is already supposed to take 'req, res'  and may be 'next' as the params.
app.get('/:myparam', file2.handler); app.param('myparam', file1.handler); file1.js >> exports.handler = function(req, res, next){ ... req.myparam=anyThingYouWantToDo;}
Thank you! this problem was resolved.
cool, you r welcome!

Please explain when do we use ' exports ' and when do we use ' module.exports ' .
Okay . But whats the benefit of using module.exports ?
Both do the same thing, the difference is in the way it is being done..
Okay , thanks !
You are welcome. Look here for more explanation - http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5311334/what-is-the-purpose-of-nodejs-module-exports-and-how-do-you-use-it
Thank you !

In the answer at the stackoverflow question , it is mentioned that " if you overwrite exports then it will no longer refer to module.exports. So if you wish to assign a new object (or a function reference) to exports then you should also assign that new object to module.exports " What does it mean ?

See ,  initially there is an object called module and a separate variable called exports.Now the object 'module' too has a property called exports.The job of this property exports is to collect all obj/functions/var that have to be 'exported' form the .js file in itself.This is what is returned from the .js file .That was about the object module and the exports inside it.Going on to the exports variable not inside module , all , the docs say is that this object also points to the module.exports property.So if you don't fiddle with it (like for eg change it like exports='10' or something) module.exports==exports will give you a true.In brief , both module.exports and exports, if you don't fiddle with exports, are the same thing .
So if you wish to assign a new object (or a function reference) to exports then you should also assign that new object to module.exports " What does it mean ? Explanation:

suppose you have a function abc(){} then , if you are doing something like exports=abc then you should also do module.exports=abc so they are pointing at the same thing.But this is stupid  ..... don't think about it ..... all i want to say is module.exports and exports are the same thing and they do the same thing , no difference at all until you make exports point to some other object apart from module.exports.
jio Akshay Nautiyal Anna
Thank you Akshay !
Also I got to know that we can directly call the functions when we assign them to module.exports , but not when we assign them using exports only .

Ishitva Goel In others word , we can say that when we use module.exports, it gives us a single item, which can be an object or a function and directly accessible. And when we use exports, it gives us a bag of stuff instead of a single item, and we have to get the required item out of the bag ourselves.
I got it now , thanks :)

Hi guys. Can you help me ? I`m getting some errors when i develop applications. I make two applications. The application one is running on XAMMP server (i call this with A ) and the other one is running on Node.JS server (i call this with B ). A is a client application that consume REST from B (B is REST server). When A consume it, i get several errors in Javascript Console on Chrome. 

It says "Failed to load resource: No 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header is present on the requested resource. Origin 'http://localhost:1212' is therefore not allowed access.". (http://localhost:1212 is XAMMP server). 

My question is, what do errors come from A (PHP) or B (Node.JS). Sorry, I can't publish that applications code on github or other, because still developing. Thank for understanding.
when A call REST Service from B. Node.JS logs a OPTION Request.. But, when I try to call REST Service with cURL Node.JS logs a GET OPTION and return data from MongoDB...

http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-origin_resource_sharing
This might be the problem ?

^ sounds like you need a cross domain.xml file on server b so server a can access it. Look that up and if you're running both servers on local host then you need to put local host in the XML file for the server.
This might help - http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19947948/apache-and-nodejs-cross-domain-ajax-issue
Its a cross origin resource sharing issue.
add following line header('Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *'); to your php source code or you can add : Header add Access-Control-Allow-Origin "*" to your htaccess
Yeah.. Thank God. The problem was solved. I try to create a REST Service using Restify and those errors doesn't show.. Ok. Thank so much friends...

data.message: What do you think about Meteor Framework? Advantages and Disadvantages?
data.name: Meteor
data.caption: www.meteor.com
data.description: Meteor is an open-source JavaScript platform for building top-quality web apps in a fraction of the time, whether you're an expert developer or just getting started.

data.message: proven and tested for interactive apps
Any disadvantages?

As for disadvantages, in my opinion, the model is not appropriate for every app. I can't see how to securely fit the Meteor model into game apps, for example. I am sure there are likely others. Then some other apps just don't benefit a lot from its data model, in which case Meteor would be over-kill. But Meteor was not written for smaller apps (and likely not for games, either). It was written with large apps in mind, to mirror what some major companies were building in their proprietary systems for very large AAA web applications.
i agree, used best with interactive web app

Also, like a ton of node tech, it is very young. It may end up being a thorn in the Meteor team that it got so much attention so fast. We have been talking about Meteor for, what, nearly 12 or 18 months now? It started getting attention at v0.2, and is now still only at v0.6. When I looked at it a while back it was still under rapid development. While node still isn't at 1.0, we can all probably agree it actually could have been months ago, or possibly even last year. But Meteor truly is a young framework that is still growing. While obviously its potential benefits outweighed that possible negative in many organizations' eyes (who are having a great time using it, of course), it should still be a consideration since using young technology can come with its own sets of challenges.
as to my experience. theres a lot of benefits using this framework rather than the disadvantages bcoz u can easily patch the disadvantages.
I don't doubt it. A lot of major players have been using it, and more than enough time has passed to know it wasn't a passing fad.

Oh, and another potential consideration: If you are working on large projects, other skilled Meteor developers are at a premium. Sure, you could hire a node dev and train them up, but if you need another dev in a serious position of responsibility and need them to have extensive previous experience with it, expect to be looking for a while and to pay a premium for them. As with most newer technologies that are released to tons of press and interest, the demand for seasoned Meteor devs far outstrips the supply.

Hi guys. What you think about AbsurdJS http://krasimirtsonev.com/blog/article/AbsurdJS-fundamentals
data.name: AbsurdJS fundamentals
data.caption: krasimirtsonev.com
data.description: AbsurdJS became one of my favorite projects. I spent a good amount of time developing it and it's getting more and more interesting. I also received some positive feedback, so I think it is time to write a bit more about the module and explain how it actually works and what exactly is made for.

data.message: that it rockz

In my opinion, it's a really cool tool for writing css with javascript, so if you need to generate some css programmatically, this could be an easy way to do it.

If you are not programmatically generating your CSS, I don't know why you would add the extra complexity of an additional API layer.

I see this as a niche tool that fills an important role between javascript and css, but not as a general tool that will replace writing your CSS in something like LESS or Stylus, which has the awesome benefit of compatibility with dropped-in vanilla CSS.
what are talking about??? angularJS has nothing to do with  CSS. is an MV* framework
We are actually talking about AbsurdJS, not AngularJS ;)

Dallas John Slieker In the beginning the library was a CSS preprocessor. Later became and HTML preprocessor. So, now it is both. It could convert javascript to HTML and CSS. The idea is that with javascript you are really really flexible.

I'm skeptical of javascript syntax being the superior way to write either css, or html in a generalized way, without the project requiring a high degree of CSS and/or HTML dynamic generation. It's simply too convenient to have cross-compatibility with vanilla CSS in Stylus for me to consider writing CSS in javascript. The loss of the cross-compatibility with vanilla CSS is a deal-breaker to me, as 3rd party creative firms won't be bothered to learn javascript in order to deliver CSS.

So again, I am not trashing the library. I think it's great! It actually gives me some cool ideas concerning html / css generation in Javascript. I am only stating that in terms of being a general utility to replace the utility of LESS, SASS, or Stylus, I think it's a horse of a different breed.
Good points indeed. Thanks for the comment.
Krasimir Tsonev Thank you very much for writing the library. I've bookmarked it, and will keep up with your progress :)

data.message:
Hi friends,
I have kind of problem with HtmlUnitDriver (headless browser)
My original client application (in java) written with selenium webdriver, uses Firefox and it works fine. Then, I decided to run it on headless browsers because this is a multi-thread program and increasing thread number to hundred thousands needs huge amount of resources. After trying different options I chose HtmlUnitDriver as a famous headless browser which is compatible with selenium webdriver.

the main problem at first was tons of "WARNING: CSS error:..." . I disabled those warnings bye disabling javascript support:

HtmlUnitDriver wd1 = new HtmlUnitDriver();
wd1.setJavascriptEnabled(false);

Now, my client application works without those WARNINGs, but request's response time (I mean response time for each clicks) is much higher in comparison to real Firefox browser.
My application executes 100 clients in parallel (multi-threading) and calculates the response time for each request (each client opens my Wordpress blog) . Specifically, the first response time in all clients (which is the first request in each client) are in the order of 12000 ms but next requests are more realistic. However, In real browser (Firefox), first request is usually in the order of 4000 ms.

I appreciate if you help me to find out what is wrong in my setup.

I can provide more information about the source code If you need.
Kindly, help me as soon as because its an emergency case.

I appreciate your supports in advance.
Amir

similarly named i said.  the name is similar.
The only other similarity would be recursiveness and dealing with structure.

It'll scrape a structure and give lots of options for loading it into memory, compiling it, requiring it, or writing it to another directory.
Cool, it's nice to make static pages too, correct?
you could.  i used it for loading every template into a global templates object since I was using coffee cup which has lacking partial support

another implementation was watching a socket.io controllers directory.  every time i called io.on('event'), i listened to that event and when that file got reloaded, I removed those events from io, so that when the file loaded back up, it would not have duplicate bindings.  that way, i could edit a file and not need to restart the whole server..  I'm thinking about doing the same thing for express routes.

Hello Everyone, I'm new to this Node.js ... i don't get it clearly when to use node.js and for what type of apps?

1. for anything you like or want
2. for realtime things
3. for high-concurrency things (many connections at once)

Almost everything older than it works under the old CGI paradigm. A form   sends data, the mainframe compute the data and produces a result page. This is okay and is easy extendible to make good interfaces.  But these days people expectations about webpages are bigger.  on a register form, people want to have the "nickname" green if the nick is available, and red if is taken. Stuff like that. More usability, easier and happier web. But using the old model is too much like pooling for resources, repeating tasks again and again (like connecting to a database, or inicializing some data).  Node.js is a smart way to support the expectations of people in a better way, paying the cost of connections and incializations only once,  having event based computing (so theres no idle resources wasting resources) and so on.
ohh thanks guys I got it now ... thanks for being so supportive ... be blessed :)

What does it mean event-driven, non-blocking I/O?
you trigger a lot of actions and the computing of action b doesn't have to wait for action a to be completed.

It takes the approach that all I/O activities should be non-blocking. This means that all HTTP requests, database queries, file I/O, and so on, do not halt execution until they return. Instead they run independently and then emit an event when the data is available.

data.message:
Hi,
I am implementing WebServer. It consists of two nodejs processes, process 1 handles all the web requests and if some request needs big computation, then it will send the request to the 2nd process, and once completed, the response will be sent back from 1st process which in turn will send back to WebClient, this is working fine, now I am planning to do some optimization, sending the response from 2nd nodejs process itself, Process 2 does some more work like continuous some specific jobs like cache updating etc.

In case 1 (send the response from process 1), I was storing the response and request context, when the response coming from process2, I was matching the context based on some request UUID, which is working perfectly using response.json or response.send.

Now how I can achieve case 2 (send the response from process2 to webClient, when the web client sent the request to process1)? In process 2, I do not have request and response object, as it can not be sent over socket using JSON.stringify.

Regards,
Mayukh.

process2 is not a child process of process1, this is an  independent process. process2 is used mainly to do some background jobs and it also handles some request coming from process1 which is for web Client.

If our brains were computers, there'd be no remove, only replace.
WHat is Meteor in relation to Node, are they two different platform to work with

Meteor is a way higher level framework on top of node. It does a bunch of things, it's highly opinionated and it lets you build realtime applications *in a breeze*.

Node is a platform.
i see, so instead of learning node and express, isnt it a good idea to jump straight into meteor

Well, if you just want results and something that works without understanding anything about it (or because you already do understand how it works), yes.

Otherwise I'd suggest you actually learn the technology you use. There's plenty of bad code out there, do yourself a favor and do not contribute to that everlasting demon.

NodeJS offers a paradigm shift, just as JavaScript does when you start using it as a proper functional/prototypical language. In the end it is more than worth it.

Yes, Meteor is opinionated full-stack framework. It's not as mature as Express.js for production yet, but should a great potential. More on frameworks at http://nodeframework.com

it many be opinionated but see this at the bottom of their mission

Meteor is backed by the world's top investors, including Andreessen Horowitz, Matrix Ventures, James Lindenbaum (Heroku), Dustin Moskovitz (Facebook, Asana), Alexis Ohanian (Reddit), Paul Buchheit (Gmail), Rod Johnson (Spring), Peter Levine (XenSource), David Skok (JBoss, SilverStream), Maynard Webb, Ron Conway, Yuri Milner, Y Combinator, and others. The project is very well funded.
What it has to do with quality or nature?

Pashu Pathi being well funded doesn't mean you're doing any good. It's likely that you are, but it's not a requisite.

I think configuration is way more powerful than opinion. That's the unix way of doing things: you set the opinionated basics (like let's all handle text files) and you leave everything else up to the user to configure.

Express.js is a de facto standard of Node.js development and the most popular NPM library as of today! However, as with any framework, sometimes the learning curve is steep. At HackReactor, I often asked the same questions about code organization, authentication, database connections and deployment.

http://webapplog.com/express-js-guide-release/

After weeks of writing and editing, Azat and his team are happy to announce the release of Express.js Guide: The Most Popular Node.js Framework Manual! The book is very approachable and suitable for beginners. If someone wants to save time searching the web and learn the best practices from the trenches, Express.js Guide is the book that has everything: Express.js API reference, quick start guides, 20+ meticulously explained examples and tutorials on over 270 pages with more than 60 illustrations.

The foreword to Express.js Guide is written by a famous Node.js developer and an open-source contributor Anatoliy Chakkaev (@1602)— the creator of CompoundJS (ex-RailswayJS) and JugglingDB.

The book contains the following parts:

Quick Start: What is Express.js? Installation, CLI, MVC Structure, etc.
The Interface: Configuration and Settings, Middlewares, Parameters, Routing
Request and Response, Running an App, Error Handling and many more
Tips and Tricks: Abstraction, Streams, Redis, Clusters, Authentication,Stylus/LESS/SASS, Domains, Security, Socket.IO, etc.
Tutorial and Examples: Instagram Gallery, Todo App, REST API and HackHall
In addition to four aforementioned major examples, there are many other smaller ones. Their full source code is available for examination at github.com/azat-co/expressjsguide.

To download Express.js Guide and start you Node.js development, choose one of these options:
