Hello, I'm digging about how to limit web socket request for example 5 per second. I can do this with a little script of course but im wonder if there is a good solution for that, maybe socket.io maybe nodejs itself or express is also provides something like that? Or maybe nginx?

I want to do this for limit chat communication, you know user can simply open console write a while loop and send server endless requests, and this gonna cause big trouble for me and other chat users.

What is the best way to do this? What do you prefer?
Thank you.

You should be throttling on either the HTTP level, when your page is being sent (and maybe make a long poll) or at the WS level by refusing a connection based on the HTTP Upgrade Headers or other client specific details.

data.message: Slides from my Presentation yesterday at Rails Israel. Read about how we used Phantom.js to save our lives.
data.name: The Dark Side of Single Page Applications
data.caption: www.slideshare.net
data.description: The story of all the pitfalls we had while transferring FTBpro.com from the good old web to a Backbone single page application... and all the great solutions we

data.message: Nice presentation! Quick question that I did not see answered on the slides: You mention on the "dark side" about Google not being able index SPAs well, which is true. Does this type of setup fix that, or at least help? I was going to try tinkering around with making an entire SPA message board, but then it hit me that it would not be indexable, which is one of the prime ways forums bring in traffic. People search for a question asked and answered on your forum and it pops up.

yes, it fixes it 100%. you use phantom.js with escaped_fragment or really as a supervised middleware like we did - and it solves it for you. you can check our SEO and see that our posts are found well (ftbpro.com). (you can also try brombone.com)
nice
is there any drawback of using many libraries.middlewear??

there is a drawback in general - but you can see we are using two layers of caching to the phantomjs-render here 1. memcached 2. cdn and so the phantom.js is not utilized for every call. we used to use Jader in a similar context instead of Phantom.js but there is no need to use them both

Thanks, Is it possible to have a wildcard route? for example profile/John or profile/Jack automatically works.
yes sorry, check my edited answer.  I understood other thing before.
You can create that type of routes checking the req.params.route on a app.get "/:route"
the * worked but in third segment of URL doctype html error happens!!! for example : localhost:4000/profile or whatever is OK but localhost:4000/profile/John is not working.

if you need that type of route for example localhost:4000/profile/John you have to register a new method that can handle that route. app.get("/profile/:username") is the way, and then you check what username is requested by checking req.params.username, the next is up to you! :)   IS VERY IMPORTANT that you let the app.get("*") the last route
I know that, I mean something like facebook. it is accessible in ALL pages. no matter where you are. is it possible in express or i should write a couple of routes for all URL?
Express routing
Explain more what you need please!

I mean, if I visit this url : localhost:4000/profile/John
I need to define a route app.get('/profile/:username')
And if I visit this url : localhost:4000/profile/John/newcomments
I need to define a route app.get('/profile/:username/newcomments')
And if I visit this url : localhost:4000/profile/John/newcomments/comment6
I need to define a route app.get('/profile/:username/newcomments/:id')

isn't any way to get rid of all this defines and just nodejs automatically detect I AM IN SAME DOMAIN so res.sendfile automatically works in all pages?
with backbone and require js
register at the bottom of middlewares in express app.use(function(req, res){   **** Here you can handle all the routes, not inside app.router ***    }); (i hope you understand what im saying)

Wildcard routes in Express only work to the next / meaning you would need a newly defined route each level down you want to go.

/:wildcard
/:wildcard/:two
/:wildcard/:two/:three
Etc

That being said, Andres is right, sounds like you want a middleware to run at the end after router to catch all of this.

I just wanted to say that Sails.js is REALLY cool. I am slapping myself now because the hours upon hours to get Socket.io and Express to work together the way I wanted was all already done and came with Sails out-of-the-box. If you use Socket.io and Express together, you owe it to yourself to check it out. Socket.io requests work just like HTTP responses, and you just use res.json() to send JSON back to them, and sessions are unified. Checking it out has been a big break for me in my node usage, I believe (I mostly use node for HTML5 games and traditional web games). Oh, and it has a nice, sensible ORM built-in, too!
http://sailsjs.org/#!
data.name: Sails.js | Realtime MVC Framework for Node.js
data.caption: sailsjs.org
data.description: Sails.js makes it easy to build custom, enterprise-grade Node.js apps. It is designed to resemble the MVC architecture from frameworks like Ruby on Rails, but with support for the more modern, data-oriented style of web app development. It's especially good for building realtime features like chat.

data.message: I felt like the same after i tried sails, but after trying it into depth it can also get frustrating :)
Out of curiosity, what did you find frustrating?

Hmm...one thing I can't seem to find so far is how you connect from the server back to clients over socket. I know there are rooms, but that doesn't solve some problems, such as sending private messages to specific users. In regular Socket.io, I just had to save all of the socket objects with their respective users into data structures to find them when needed. Does anyone know of an elegant way to handle this in Sails?

Sails allows access to socket.io with sails.io

Socket.get/put/etc is simply a method for ease of use. You can still use socket.io per normal conventions.

I'm not a nodejs developer, but looking at it's name and logo reminds me of Rails. I've read it's documentation and everything is in a similar fashion with Laravel and Rails framework. Is this a Rails clone for Node.JS? If so, my happiness level will be over nine thousand.

It isn't a clone, per se, but it is influenced by it. There have been a couple of frameworks that have tried to actually be Rails clones in node, and most of them have met with lukewarm reactions (just trying to force Rails style when it doesn't fit with Javascript, for example). But Sails is more influenced by it rather than cloning it, and breaks with it in some ways where it doesn't fit with JS, or there is a better way to handle a concern in JS. I am only moderately familiar with Rails, so I can't go item-by-item, but the basic answer is that it has a Rails feel, without trying to be a mirror image.

Reece Lewellen, do you think that when I need to push data to clients that I should drop down to raw Socket.io sockets? Due to the prettiness of the socket-friendly controllers, I was hoping maybe I was missing something, but that is probably the answer. I know Sails has great support for Pub/Sub, but I don't think that will help me a ton since often I need to push data based on server-side logic, rather than model updates (common for online games). Thank you!
Yea, I suggest custom server logic for stuff like that. Basic sub pub sails updates are great for blogs and like... Client database GUIs.

Thanks! Hey, do you know what the overhead on rooms are in Sails sockets? Do you know if it using Socket.io rooms underneath the surface? Those could be quite useful for online games, particularly if they don't have huge overhead :)
> Out of curiosity, what did you find frustrating?  Try to set a Attribut in waterline to be unique :)
Hmm...true that. There doesn't seem to be an attribute for that. But that doesn't really bother me much, as that is easy enough to do yourself.
I am not using it, but I agree ... well done!
This was just one example :)

Hi guys, 
Did someone already tried to develop real-time Node applications with Socket.IO?

Simone Fabiano recently divulged some interesting results of a true apple-to-apple comparison between Lightstreamer and socket.io in a data broadcasting scenario ran over two Amazon EC2 machines (messages generated on the server side to >4k clients). Lightstreamer scaled way more efficiently in terms CPU consumption, latency and required bandwidth, and it can be clustered and put behind a common load balancer, so the number of clients can be even (way) higher. The same benchmark is also on GitHub, so you can try it yourself if you want, and I will be glad to assist if needed. [full disclosure: I work for Lightstreamer].

Hey, Guys, thanks for accepting me as a new part of this group.
I have a very basic question. I have seen some videos and tutorials about making applications using node js and it's dependencies modules, and in all of them, they use host:port to access the pages in web browser. ex: localhost:3000
does it needed on the web to write port at the end of the URL ?
I mean : How to have an application using nodejs ON THE WEB, without writing port at the end of our URL?
Sorry if it is a very basic question.
I think you can map http://serverip:port to a domain address when hosting your application on a web-host which provides node.js hosting !).
So you mean there is no need to specify the port on a web host?

You can tell your application to host on port :80 (the default http port) even in development on your localhost (if you wanted).

Is it the default express app (eg '$ express myAppName' ?

If you dig around, you will see where the port is specified in your application or framework. If you are using Express, you will probably see something like:
app.set('port', process.env.PORT || 3000);
If you want to change process.env.PORT, on Linux just enter:
$ export PORT = 80
node app.js
On Windows, just change the first line to:
set PORT = 80
Most node frameworks default to a high port for development, because many apps use 80 that you don't even think about, and you will get a cryptic port in use error (Skype I know can hold it, and so can some development web servers and SQL Server tools).
Oh, and by "change the first line to", I mean the first line of the shell commands I listed right above it, not the first lines of the code, of course :)

Thank you guys, I just wanted to know is it necessary to enter the port at the end of the url while the application is on a web host, not localhost. I just forgot that a domain name is combination of host:port !!!
Start with port 80

Port 80 is the default port of the web. If your application responds to port 80, then no, users will not have to add the port to the URL. Only if it is something besides port 80 will they have to add it to the URL. It is considered a best practice to only use port 80 for sites in production. But for development using another port is fine.

I think it is an apt comparison, and once you get further into the article he clears up that they are not directly equivalent (he just  probably should have done that sooner). But the decision of "PHP vs. node" is important because many people are having to weigh in their minds whether to start a new web app with a PHP framework or a node web framework. There is a comparison in there somewhere, because people are having to make it. Obviously node can do much more than PHP can outside of web development, but so can Java and people compare things like "Symfony vs. Struts/Play/etc." all the time.

Hello guys. I have a "little" of a question. Does deploying a node.js app to a cloud hosting provider require me to use the cluster module to benefit from scaling on multiple cores (as node is single threaded)? If yes, is there some kind of thread management which needs to be done manually? If no, how does it work at all?

dude javascript itself is a single threaded, and nodejs is single threaded multiple process architecture. cluster or clusterjs is used to generate multiple workers of same server where each can share same port. eg. in four core processor if iwant clustering then lets say we took 4 as a baseline so in clustering it will make one master process and other 3 are workers. this way u can increase performance. very useful if u r creating node http server.

Hi all,

I've recently been working on a new release of We Listen. We Listen allows people to listen to the same music through the SoundCloud API. It has some great new features such as:

- Facebook integration: you can now use We Listen from within Facebook and share rooms/tracks with your friends
- SoundCloud integration: when you enter a room, connect with SoundCloud to easily add your favourite tracks and the tracks you have uploaded
- Listen to the same tracks with up to 100 people
- Auto-filled playlists: join the "auto-playlist" room, based on genres and listen to tracks selected by the server. You can still add your own tracks though
- Heart songs you like: when you like a song in a playlist, heart it, so it goes up in the playlist queue
- More

We Listen is currently in closed Beta on Facebook. If you want to join our testers team, please comment below.

You can also test the app outside of Facebook:
https://intern.npsoftware.nl:81/

 Thanks in advance!

Hi Everyone,
I am building a application in nodejs with express framework, I am stuck at error handling concept, read some blogs about it, still didn't got it completely. How we do error handling in nodejs.
In express you generally pass middleware with err as first paramater in middleware
You're looking for a global error handler that keeps your app always running ? no matter what happens

Syntax errors or critical errors that crash your app could be handled with this event http://nodejs.org/api/process.html#process_event_uncaughtexception

Errors from async functions can be passed to next() and you can set up a route/middleware handler to display an error page and log the error.

Thanks yulumber, Alejandro Amador and Sam Holmes, whatever i know you can pass errors in callback , as node being single process machine, few error stops the process, how you handle it in a production system...when lot if users are using your app and you couldnt afford to stop only process available because of any code error....

Very few people do web development directly in node without a framework, which makes it quite unlike things like PHP. It is just far too low level. The wonderful Connect project gave us a nice set of middleware that starts to turn node into a competent web platform, and then Express takes it the rest of the way to be a full web development choice. However, compared to some other modern frameworks, such as Rails, Symfony, Laravel, ASP.NET MVC, etc., it feels a bit lacking and a bit unrefined. Others have answered that call with more complete web frameworks for node, such as Sails.js and Compound. Almost all web frameworks are built from Express and build it out further, so even if you don't end up directly using Express, it is great to learn it first before moving on.
And Geddy !
http://geddyjs.org/
What do you think about TypeScript ? Yah or Nah ?

Yet another symptom of a company that thinks its artificial standards will be adopted because they are its standards, while ignoring what exists. 
And I don't even mention the crappy design choices struggling to rely on the strength of other things that are of a different context.
I mean, if you are interested in a language / architecture, you should first understand it, and not try to create a superset to try to use it as something else you used to before.
to concise : bloated egos, causing a blinding indoctrination, leading to: the fragmentation of technology, and poor practices.

And the worst thing: All the beginners that still don't understand javascript, kinda afraid, left to their own, which will hear talking of this, leaving the common sense in favor of the "easy way" mutilating their own mind.

I don't agree with Kane totally. I mean having static typing is good, actually it's about the same if you use jsdoc and google closure compiler... What Kane Talked about is rather about Dart imho... ("creating something else you used before" -> well, Dart is almost like Java, but Typescrip is much closer to Javascript... :])

if you need static types in javascript: you're doing it wrong. Both Dart and TypeScript are for those who didn't grasp JS, they are just impeding crutches. the fact is that js is so different, and somewhat so close in a way, from all the C derived language that you need to reformat your brain for, but it worth it !

It is really not close to any C-like language... That's only the syntax... I guess you are talking about functional programming, if yes, you are right... :) But even in functional programming it's nice to have static typing. Consider Scala or Haskell...

Gyula, i.e. static types… Sounds like C++ for me, maybe I'm wrong.
What I meant was: Javascript look like one of the C childs, but it is not really, it's one of the deterring feature for newcomers, they try to write JS like it's PHP or Java or C# or <insert historical server-side language here for "true developer that don't lower themselves to be on front" *sarcasm*>.
As I see it, MS and Google just try to flirt with those deterred newcomers by offering them a cheap fake solution (in France, we use a german term back from the WWII: ersatz), so they never really evolve, they never grasp the good parts of JS…
"if you are interested in a language / architecture, you should first understand it, and not try to create a superset to try to use it as something else you used to before." +1
I think static typing might be nice, since you can have more advanded ide features no?

Yes, it can, but adding this kind of feature increase the difficulty of making concise seemless polymorphism. It's like the fight between manual memory handling and garbage collectors… Who has the power ? 
Do you trust your fellow coworker to write "good enough" code, or even doing things you didn't planified by hacking (in the good part of the word) your classes/objects/API ?
isnt typescript compiling to vanilla js ?
btw i prefer plain js

I think, that in fine, given TS compile to JS, and TS app can consume JS, it's a question of methodology.
Do you really want to work using the classes as proposed by TS ?
And remember, I don't know the code quality/readability of the compiled TS, it's something to take in account too.

Yeah, I agree, using classes in ts is not a good idea, since there is no concept like that in js. But eg. indicate the type of a parameter is a very good idea... (That is why I compared it with using google closure compiler...) So don't misunderstand me, I write purely functional js code, but still I think static typing is a good idea, since lot of errors can be catched in compile time... Kane Þórnwyrd, do you feel this hatred towards coffeescript as well? :)
classes?..or another geek workaround?

It's not hatred, it's just a big red warning for those who believe that a language or a superset may be a silver bullet.
.
BTW, there is classes in ES6… Just sayin…
.
Coffeescript is not flawless in my eyes, since the js resulting is far from what I can write, optimization-wise. But at least it give some decent shortcut and the syntax is a real pro (for me at least).
Yeah, but es6 looks like a totally different language :) Actually have you guys been playing around with es6? Are those classes identical to the "classical" oo classes?

Hey all!!. I come from traditional programming languages: Python and Java, in where the form of you structure your program and apply design software patterns is well known. Although I know that design is itself a discipline, i do not find examples of apply that patterns on a big project with node. 

i am currently developing a big application. I started with that project 20 days ago and now i feel that my code starts to look messy. I am using express. Can you recommend any books or resources that have examples of how to organize and make architecture with node?

Node.js being an ECMAscript implementation should not be that hard to structure. If you follow common module structure of your application you should be fine. Just remember that the module location is the namespace.

Does it really matter? As long as you can "get to" the code that you want, then you're good. What I try to do is isolate my code into files that handle a specific section of the site. If you're using express, then you most likely have a lot of route handlers. Say you have a blog section on your site. Create a file called blogs.js, store it in /routes folder, then require('./routes/blog.js') to access all the methods you export. Use the exported methods as callbacks to app.get/post/all/etc. This way you're main app.js file looks like a list of routes and where to find the routes. Also, each aspect of you're site is separated into modules. If blogs.js gets to big, you could break it down even further, but try to keep things as simple as possible and re-use code through node_modules whenever possible. – My 2 cents.

I think that really it matters, when you work with many people and you expect that your project can be scalable the architecture is really important. I was looking of pattern software application and I found a book that helps me: http://www.addyosmani.com/resources/essentialjsdesignpatterns/book/

I think it's not a good idea to force yourself to use the good old object oriented patterns, since the best part of javascript is that it has functional properties! It's much better if you concentrate on that. (Imho)

As Felipe Triana Castañeda pointed out, many design patterns have been ported to JS. Some that didn't really don't apply due to JS's prototype-based nature rather than traditional OOP. There are also some patterns beginning to emerge that focus on  asynchronous programming in node, but that is still ongoing.

A post of the basics of functional Javascript was born today, you can check it out in my blog. I'm planning to write about the functional patterns used in js, you will find them in the next few weeks. Here is the post about the basics: http://www.jsmage.com/2013/08/the-very-basics-functions-in-javascript.html  I hope that will help.
The next post about functional programming in Js: http://www.jsmage.com/2013/08/function-composition.html There's a video on the end, that is amazing!!! (So do not skip it.) :)
Hey guys, I'm wondering, on some forum, when you go to a post, under it, it says 'username aaa, username bbb are reading this post'. What's the idea behind 'viewing a page' detection?

i guess that when a user logs in, you add them to a list of "connected users" and their last time of activity, and after every 5 minutes (to say a number) if they havent had any activity you remove them from that list
I think this can be done better with redis and socket.io

The forums I suppose function as Rene said. It's a functionality that has been implemented throughout the whole last decade at least, so it couldn't be very sophisticated. Redis and socket.io would be, in theory, a very polished implementation that gives out the most up to date information but I'm not sure if the value of the information balances out the performance issues related to having an always-on connection for each of the connected clients, especially in contexts like forums where there might be a large number of logged-in users.

Im trying to do it with socket.io, how it works now is that everytime someone access the url of the webpage (aka send a GET request to the url), it saves its username to an array of online users on server side, then when an user closes the webpage, it send a socket to server, then the server upon receiving this event, will remove this user from the array. However, problem arises when an user opens more than one page. The algorithm now keep inserting his username into the array, then remove it when he closes the page. So when he opens the page twice, then close once, i can still know he has one page left opened.   But this counter method is very buggy. Mainly if someone keep refreshing the page like crazy, socket io doesn't send data that quickly, the online users array will just keep growing without decreasing (because sockets delay). You guys mentioned Redis, may I know more how it works to achieve an reasonable 'who is viewing page' algorithm?
You could add a timestamp to the array and remove entries older than, say, 10 minutes.
Redis sets can add new elements only if not exists on that set.  check: http://redis.io/topics/data-types#sets
A good case...

Who can help to work with node.js and django web framework?  Please
What are you needing to do in node that can't be handled in Django? That would help us with the direction

Keep in mind that Python has the excellent Twisted evented asynchronous system, which is very similar to node, such as allowing you to use WebSockets easily, etc. If you are already heavily invested in Django and Python, it may be easier and cleaner to keep all your logic under one roof. Of course, I am a fan of node and Socket.io, so if you haven't started, you can definitely move everything into node with Express or a derived web framework and Socket.io.
I started with node and i got a good result,  my postgresql database  now can inform node that there is new data & node push it to specific connected client, i think it's enougth!!!

If you are using Django because it is a more complete framework than Express (which you would be right), I can understand. But there are more full-featured web frameworks for node that derive from Express. CompoundJS is a framework that is winning over node devs all over. I think you would benefit from keeping everything in one platform. http://compoundjs.com

I will check what can i do

No problem :)
SailsJS rocks as well :)
Ahh, yes, thank you Reece. SailsJS is another popular, more feature-rich web framework for node.
Both of those would likely match the functionality in Django. Express is really a better base for further framework abstraction.
The problem is that a big part of the application is built,  my task is to integrate a framework that allow real time data display in our django template
When you were wanting to get node and Django to work together, what features were you needing from node?

Oh sorry, you said real-time data display lol. Check out Twisted. It is really under the same philosophy as node, but it is 100% Python. Your Python devs would probably be more comfortable with it as well. http://twistedmatrix.com/trac/
There is a friend who suggested to me that I work with node.js & socket.io
I built it, & it works fine

That is kind of the default answer today for real-time web data, but it definitely isn't the only choice. Python has Twisted, Ruby has Event Machine and .NET has SignalR (although SignalR would be more closely related to Socket.io than node). These can play the same role on their specific platforms that node plays. I just suggest this because you are going to complicate your development (in my humble opinion) by bringing a whole different platform for the real-time side of your application. If you are invested in Python, I suggest to stay invested in Python. At the worst, you may have to double your work load by splitting it between 2 platforms.
For websockets, you can use Autobahn with Twisted. There are also several different WS implementations for Twisted on Github if that one doesn't work  http://autobahn.ws/python
Sorry, you built which already? The Django side, right?
I'm newest on django development,  that's why I got the worst ride
Hmm...but the Django side is mostly built is what you were saying, right?
SailsJS comes prepackaged with socket.io functionality throughout the server. That said, Tim is right. Either use node or python but I would not mix.

(Man, I need to check out SailsJS lol) Saif, I would stay with the platform you have the most work done on already. It sounds like that is the Python side. If changing totally to node means re-doing weeks or months worth of work, it most definitely is not worth it, and that is coming from a huge node fan.
The real time display work fine, I used node& socket.io as middleware between database and django template

Please help me which  web programming language/technology should i use for this my university project? thanks 

jQuery Mobile Icon Bank

This mobile web application will allow users to view, download and rate icons. Designers will add icons to the web site in different resolutions. The icons will be saved in albums. Registered users will view, download, email, and rate icons. Favorite icons feature will also be provided to the registered users. The application will provide filter based search features to search from all the available icons.

The application will be mainly developed in jQuery Mobile frame work. With jQuery Mobile, HTML5 and CSS, mobile web applications can be developed. For server side operations any modern web programming language/technology can be used. The application must ensure uniform UI experience across different screensizes (mobile, tablet, normal PC screen).

Users: 
- Registered: Designer, Customer, Admin
- Guest

For All Users:

1. Search page will allow following options:
- Cost (Free/Priced)
- Resolution (16x16, 24x24, 32x32, 48x48, 64x64, 72x72, 96x96, 128x128)
- Color Scheme (Pure Black n White/Color)

2. On search results, user should be able to view, and download icons. The view mode will allow customers to view icons in different resolutions (as in previous point).

3. Rating will be displayed with each icon in search results, and also it will be displayed in View mode.

4. Top ten (10) rated icons should be displayed on the home page of the application.

For Customer:

3. On the search page, it should provide same options as mentioned in point number 1, plus the option to assign rating to any icon.

4. In case of free icon, customer should be able to email the icon (either a URL or the actual icon for email attachment).

5. In case of priced icon, the customer should be able to email the designer.

6. Customers should be able to add an icon to the Favorite Icons list. A separate page should be available to manage favorites.

For Designer:

7. Create albums.

8. Designer should be able to add, delete, and replace existing icons in the albums.

For Admin:

9.  Admin will perform following managerial tasks:
- Add/Update/Delete User
- Modify content of the About Us/Contact Us page

Additional information:

Icons will be provided in PNG format.

Tools:
jQuery Mobile
HTML5 & CSS
Any modern web programming language tools:
(Asp.Net or Asp.net MVC with C#.Net/VB.Net, PHP, ROR etc.)
Use whatever you have experience with or wawnt to learn. The project is realizable in all of those.

After inspecting several MVC frameworks, I would like to crown Compound.js as the most mature, production ready, versatile and (relatively) well documented framework for this purpose. I strongly recommend you check it out, especially if you're coming from Rails. (In comparison to: Sails, Meteor, Derby, Locomotive and Tower)
data.caption: Attachment UnavailableThis attachment may have been removed or the person who shared it may not have permission to share it with you.

data.message: I worked on compound as well for a few weeks (and i also designed the logo btw) and I have to say that at the state when I was working on it, it was not production ready. IMHO anatoliy is overchallenged as to maintaining the repository.

I agree there's still work to be done, that's why I hope the Node community will adopt Compound and contribute more to it, so Anatoliy will not have to carry this burden alone. All in all, I think it's the best MVC for Node we have at the time, and the most mature of them all. Hopefully it would become the next Rails for Node.

How does it compare to Express? I mostly use Express for web app development, but I can definitely see a lot to be desired particularly coming to node from some of the more mature and full-featured PHP frameworks.
Compound, like the other frameworks I mentioned, are all base on Express - so the base is solid. The exception is Meteor, which is non-npm and non-express, functioning as an independent eco-system

Ahh, thanks! I found the official website and learned quite a bit more about it. I may have to try this out for my next web app. Express is great, and solid as you said. But compared to ASP.NET MVC, Rails or a modern PHP framework, it leaves a lot of pieces missing. I guess that is where the frameworks that build off of Express come in :)
http://geddyjs.org seams to be quite robust either

data.message: In asynchronous programming, how can tasks being executed as the same time waiting for I/O? Since computer can only execute one instructions at a time..

at very core its basically infinitly  running loop that keep checking for new instructions as they come. then there are other algorithms (OS) those make sure it stays healthy and not stuck at executing something huge. they divide instructions in small instructions and make it execute in round robin fashion. Which seems like realtime because it happens at microsecond scale.  I may not be correct if its exactly round robining because its a vast area ..
The event loop in Node only executes one callback at a time. So don't hang around in a callback otherwise, you're blocking.
unless you need something from that callback, other stuff you can do already
there is a event stack and being executed in First in First Out order..

Freelance programmer needed. Apply here: http://ow.ly/mQRov
Description:
Library for JQuery & Phonegap to consume .NET Web Service

We have web services written in .NET SOAP and we would like to consume it using JQuery. The JQuery will be running inside PhoneGap solution

1. There are 40 method in the web service, they will be provided for you

2. Create the JS file that contain methods with the same name as the web service methods

3. Consume the appropriate web service when the javascript is being called. (for example: when user call javascript method HelloWorld(), it will call web service with method HelloWorld, and return the value from the web service as return value of the javascript method.

4. The javascript method is calling web service from a different origin, so you need to put into consideration cross origin resource sharing implementation.

5. Some of the return value is .NET dataset or datatable in XML and being zipped using GZipStream, so the JQuery need to unzip them and return in format that can be easily read by javascript.

Look forward to hear from you

If you are using MongoDB this may interest you.

Announcing TokuMX 1.0:  Increase Ingestion Speed and Shrink the Storage Footprint of MongoDB Applications
 
You love MongoDB for its ease of use, but is the size of your database causing you to hit limits? TokuMX™, the new storage engine from Tokutek®, can drastically increaseMongoDB's ingestion speed (20x) and reduce the storage footprint (5x) without your having to change a single line of code.  You also get ACID transactions with MVCC out of the box to simplify development.
 
TokuMX is open source and you can try it today. Here are a free few resources to help you get started:
Download TokuMX
Webinar - Introduction to TokuMX June 26, 2:00PM EDT
Webinar - Get Started with TokuMX July 9, 2:00PM EDT
See for yourself what TokuMX can do for you, and start building applications faster than ever before, smaller than ever before, and without expensive server upgrades. Visit Tokutek.com to learn more, and if you have any additional questions do not hesitate to contact us.  

About Tokutek Inc.
Tokutek, Inc. is the leader in high-performance and agile database storage engines. Tokutek uses patented Fractal Tree® indexing technology to scale MySQL, MariaDB and MongoDB from GBs to TBs, and provide improved query performance, excellent compression, and online schema flexibility. TokuDB requires no changes to  applications or code and is fully ACID and MVCC compliant. The company is headquartered in Lexington, MA and has offices in New York, NY. For more information, visit tokutek.com.

data.message: Is node.js faster than using php, ruby (ror), or python?
definitely, by using asynchronous methods.
I've seen some benchmarks on vert.x that were quite impressive too: http://vertx.io/
Trick question. It depends on what you're doing with it.
cpu intensive tasks shouldn't be faster by default, but handling many connections is easier from what I've read
Say facebook and twitter and youtube - which would benefit the most from Node.js vs Vert.x?
hard to say and I don't really know anything about vert.x than some benchmarks which don't take huge apps like facebooks gigabyte thick package into any account

If you're looking for "the technology" to get into, there is no such thing. There is, however, becoming better at programming and just learning more, like async and callbacks in node.js, or network technology and protocols, building projects along the way

Good point Jonathan.  I think Zuckerberg talked about today's languages and how he couldn't even give good advice on them (because they are so different from what he was working with back in PHP days).
Interested by this vert.x approach though.  The fact that it is multi-thread is seemingly a major advantage over Node.js but again I wouldn't say I'm an expert in either.
Has anyone else tried vert.x?  Is it stable?  The fastest asynchronous setup (because of its Java/multithread capabilities)?

JS day and night :)
There is a nice book that takes it very slow called http://www.nodebeginner.org/

Althought might be a good idea to review Javascript on w3school just to cover the basics:

I think the big difference in learning node is realizing that you are dealing with a 'server language' and not really a 'browser scripting language'. So expectations are a bit different. You would need to understaand what is required from a web server.

data.name: Douglas Crockford: “Java was a colossal failure...JavaScript is succeeding because it works.”
data.caption: jaxenter.com
data.description: For Java developers, JavaScript used to be a much-maligned territory. They‘ve just never got on with each other, despite similarnames. But as the years have worn on, the shunned language is starting to stand up for itself.Our colleague from German-language PHP Magazin, Tom Wießeckel, spoke to JavaScript god Douglas Crockford recently and we thought it was well worth hearing the guru's views on JavaScript, jQuery and CoffeeScript. Tom Wießeckel: I’m here with Douglas Crockford at JavaScript Days 2012 in Cologne. Mr. Crockford, please introduce yourself!Douglas Crockford: I’m Douglas Crockford from Yahoo! Wießeckel: You’re well known as a JavaScript super hero and you just held your keynote at the JavaScript Days. Can you summarize it?Crockford: JavaScript is becoming an important language, but it’s a misunderstood language. So in order to use it well it’s necessary to have specific information and I am trying to help provide that to people. Wießeckel: So why is that misunderstood?Crockford: A lot of it is because of its strange history. You know, the fact that it is called JavaScript. It has nothing to do with Java. It is almost like it was intentional that the name was created to confuse people. Wießeckel: You said something about the good parts and the bad parts. Which one is the worst part?Crockford: The worst part is JavaScript’s reliance and global variables. The security problems that we see in the browser are rooted in that mistake.Wießeckel: After your keynote there was a question about CoffeeScript. Can you repeat?Crockford: CoffeeScript is a new language which compiles into JavaScript. It uses JavaScript as an execution language. CoffeeScript is beautiful and elegant …

database:Mongodb

can we develope a game using above architecture ?  Let any issues

issues, one comes to mind is using two different languages, not a big one but makes me ask why not just use express+connect and serve the profile/login interface through nodejs as well? Otherwise, create a restful api between your php site and the nodejs/mongo back end that utilizes json.
if using express+connect  login problem occurs in  few operating systems  .Few antivirus are  blocking  nodejs web application
so that's why im planing to implement  php  on frontend?
http://blog.mediarain.com/2012/02/the-socket-io-protocol/
https://github.com/LearnBoost/socket.io/wiki/Socket.IO-and-firewall-software
why can the front end use normal http request to node.js

Well the problem there is not with Node.js or the JavaScript that is sent across the wires that the browser would interact with but with the antivirus manufacture's them self. All you really need to do is run your app behind a reverse proxy (like nginx) and have things setup for SSL. Easy stuff, there's guides on how to do this all over the web and I even show you how to do that in my Webinar series.
Can I ask why the need for proxy if you can simply port forward in iptable? is it because you run other services?

db.find( { ... } ).sort( { ... }).skip(n).limit(m)

The data you want to 'paginate' is first searched and sorted using find and sort. You then skip the number (n) entries you've already displayed and limit (m) to the number you'd like to display next. Your client-side JS or server-side JS will have to remember how many you've already displayed, so you know the correct n and m numbers when making the ajax callback.

depend on your data. most of the time I do add a field last_modified with unix_timestamp in the data. during the update i will {$set: (new date).getTime() } to update the timestamp. during the request you pass the last timestamp to your query along with other criteria. db.customer.find({last_modified: {$gt: last_timestamp}, customer_type : 1 }).limit(page_size). going back to previous page you will use $lt of course. This is good for display all data sorted by last_modify/last_created. Just like facebook user will start looking at the most recent update to the oldest.
The same can do for ObjectId if you need the data to display in the order you have enter. db.customer.find({_id: {$gt: ObjectId(last_id)}, customer_type : 1 }).sort({_id:1}).limit(page_size)

npm has a few issues for browser js
it will happily get many different versions of the same package, which works great on the server-side
but obviously with the browser you want to try and find a set of package versions which mean you don't need to ship 5 versions of jquery to the browser

data.message:
How do you structure your NodeJS {Express} Applications?

For Example, you like to create a Application which use Mongo Native.
How do you implement the Database Module so that you can reuse it (DRY)
How about the CRUD functionality, how do you manage to reuse this ?
Or do you just put anything in the according route?
Are you the Event guy ? who extensively use custom events to wire all together?
Or do you love to use the global object to connect things together?

I am just curious how you guys approach building Applications.
Me too...

I'm using the vhost-functionality from express and create subdirectories for my domains. It works like a normal webserver and I can use the modules on all projects. For zero downtime reload (to refresh the configs or add a new vhost for example) I use "up" as a daemon. https://github.com/LearnBoost/up
I don't mean the structure of multiple apps , I was referring to a app itself.

I want to know this too.
I think Helder Santana  may know this.

OK i start, at the moment I use the global object as entry point for any module, since I do not have to pass the app to each single module. eg: global.app.UserProvider.findAll(callback) is ANYWHERE accessable in teh whole app without ant require.
Is there an easier way ?
I think it could help you http://howtonode.org/express-mongodb
But if you are using MVC you cant let your database global, the correct is put only in model layer
@Helder Santana >http://howtonode.org/express-mongodb I know it but it is anything else than reuseable and modular :)
@Ganesh Kumar: so you built your apps like the mvc example ?

you can define your db connection in its own module, then whereever you need it(in your model files), just include the file. ==> No need for global variables.. In a UsersModel constructor:  function UsersModel(){ this.db = require('../setup/mongodb.js').connection; ..... } ....................... To avoid multiple connections when including the file many times: in setup/mongodb.js: var conn = null;  exports.connection = mongoskin.router(function(){ if(!conn){ conn = require('mongoskin').db("localhost:27017/....") } return conn;}) ...
I guess you guys get the thread here wrong, I do not ask for help , I just like to discuss different approaches.
I use Mongo Native, I create my own global object name application under node_modulel. I am more comfortable doing  require('application') at the top of the file where I need it.

You can write each model if u want in a different file, like any other backend language. And require they in your controller wich really uses. 

I think this can be a way out.

We are looking for an senior level developer with open source experience who will:
● be a knowledge base for their teammates and also the node.js community

You love this opportunity, because you:
● love solving problems with code

data.message:
Hello, first of all, thanks for accepting me in this group, is a truly challenge to post programation issues in english, i'm not sad about that, i feel i can learn a lot from both languages (english and Javacript), i'll do my best and i apologize if you can't read me so well ^^.

I wanted to ask, what is wrong with this fragment of code?

http://pastebin.com/qKJiLZbS

I'm testing that code from the following page:

http://pastebin.com/8DcNtPug

I used '$' to name variables to evade problems with any other variable pre-defined in JavaScript

In "Valor valor para el campo de texto", should say "Value to insert in the input text field", i forgot to translate, sorry n_n

I have to say that "url in my localhost" has the elements i'm trying to get XD

Thanks ^_^ .

In the view of the computer, it's not important how you name your variable. In the view of a programmer, it should have a speaking name. As well, I prefer $varname to show other programmers: "This is a jQuery-Element variable".
Your problem in your example is your variable declaration. You use "var $page", but you call it with "this.$page". You declared not an object variable, but a variable in the local scope.
There are two ways you can fix it:
1. declare it so: this.$page = ...
2. or remove "this." in the returning function
In your html file you call the method $objPageHandler.getPagina() which does not exist. You named it "getPage()"

have fun and keep on hacking ^^

data.message:
How does everybody feel about IcedCoffeeScript? As I started rewriting my Rails application to Node.js, I have headaches about all the unnecessary nesting of my code.

IcedCoffeeScript solves this problem by letting you implicitly create callback functions with await/defer "macro".

Here's my snippet of code that is responsible for authentication: First it checks with the model if username and password are correct, and if they are, it generates new token and calls the callback with that.

Please tell me how do you feel about it: Which one is the most readable? Which one do you think is the best?

https://gist.github.com/2336321

Also, about debugging: I know it's an issue, but I believe it's only a matter of time before somebody comes up with a smart solution of debugging Node.js code written in CoffeeScript. (I think source maps in browsers do that, right?)
data.name: JavaScript vs. CoffeeScript vs. IcedCoffeeScript — Gist
data.caption: gist.github.com

data.message: I think the concept and idea is cool, but i like my code nested. I wouldn't use the new keywords when it's not necessary (2 or 3 indentations is still well readable).
And in my opinion, if you have more than 2 or 3 indentations, you should think about your code structure... because then something's wrong with your code - tidy it up then :)

data.message: I would love some feedback on Common Node. It uses fibers to implement a number of synchronous CommonJS proposals & lets you write portable, synchronous server side JavaScript while retaining the performance benefits of the event loop.
data.caption: Attachment UnavailableThis attachment may have been removed or the person who shared it may not have permission to share it with you.

data.message: Here's a talk I did on this in Berlin last week: http://slideshare.net/olegp/server-side-javascript-going-all-the-way
Why did I feel this conceptually  that bad... ?
What do you mean by "conceptually bad"? Do you think it's against the Node way somehow?
Maybe a little bit against js itself...

In what way? Just because JS doesn't have language features for dealing with fibers/threads, doesn't mean you can and should not use them. C doesn't have them either, but most multi-threaded code is written in C. 

Also, they are easy enough to use with the likes of RingoJS & Web Workers are addressing the same issues.

Sorry, I don't mean to upset you, but how can you make "synchronous server side JavaScript while retaining the performance benefits of the event loop"... Per se synchronous server mean blocking process... So, to maintain performances, against asynchronous non-blocking app,  you have to split functions executions in different threads to parallel processing them...

But what's the point of doing this in a natively full async environment ?

I'm dev too, and I know too well how this is *hem* "boring" when someone act like a brainless noob and miss the point of something awesome you tried to explain to him...

So, Do you have some use cases to bring the light in the cavern that used to be my head... ? Please ?

If you have a spare 20 minutes, please listen to the presentation I linked to in the first comment - it's all explained there. 

To summarize: common-node uses fibers i.e. lightweight threads with a 64KB stack and co-operative multitasking, as opposed to OS threads and pre-emptive multitasking. 

The point of doing this is that your code becomes shorter, easier to maintain and portable.
I dont like even idea of fibers... ;( Why someones want try to cut something what makes language special ? o_O
What do you think fibers is removing from the language? If anything, it adds to it.

Which database is best with NodeJS? Redis and MongoDB both are perform well in NodeJS,But my thinking is Redis is better then MongoDB what is your idea ??

Read this, know what your project requirement is and then choose the database . And database server has to work on its own , so it doesn't matter that you use it with node.js or some other backend framework or language . You just use the wrapper to use that database. 
http://kkovacs.eu/cassandra-vs-mongodb-vs-couchdb-vs-redis
Redis is just a key-value store while MongoDB is a document store. Redis is used for storing info such user sessions, tokens and MongoDB is used for storing actual user data.
That's like comparing fish to cats. Completely different ballgames.
nothing better. It's all depend on the usecase.

I will answer my own question for 1st time : * Mongo uses javascript, Redis uses Lua 
* Mongo has MapReduce 
* Mongo uses JSON, Redis a proprietary protocol 
* both are schema free 
* Redis is optimzed for performance, and its store resides in memory 
* Mongo is document based, Redis is key-value based 
and more 

As a matter of fact, you can use both MongoDB and Redis at the same time. When you have to deal with data that is best modeled as documents, store them in mongo. When you have data that's id-value, you can store in redis. 

Example: a social service with posts and comments, where comments are a lot and highly dynamic, you can store posts in mongo and comments in redis, and link the 2 parts from the application. 
Posts in mongo let you have structured collections and documents (a post linked to an author who has connections, etc.). Comments are linked to one post only, so they are ID-Comment pairs (but comment can be a composite type) 

I suggest to read the official documentation of both engines and decide on your own which one best fits with your needs.
Then why did you ask this question here, when you can go and read the official documentation??
After u guys commented i read the docs and read the diff between the two db and then concluded .. thank u all :)
for the future, please go read up on things BEFORE asking questions. in most cases, there will be no question left ;) - don´t be lazy
Nishant Sharma see this..
I like it when people ask questions. It stimulates conversation and often causes me to research my own thoughts even further.  Besides, isn't that the whole point of this page?
it is, but not if you did not even do some basic research on your own first. that´s like letting someone else use google for you.
Redis and Mongo is used for different purposes ... so know ur purpose and finalize which one to use ....
Because the question was posted, I learned something that I wasn't even looking for. But I will have it in mind when I do need it.

Andreas Teufel , so what man ? 
why do you keep stressing on one thing that is not teaching someone something. 
Pratik Sah , I appreciate you asking this question here , because groups are made to discuss . We learnt from it and its nowhere written that you should google before you come here , because sometimes we need  direct explanation to things and expect it from such groups.

i am not "stressing" anything, just stating my opinion. googling before asking questions is a pretty basic rule for every developer. you will never become a serious developer if you don´t try to solve stuff on your own before asking. it´s also easier to learn stuff if the one who asks comes here with some basic knowledge already.
but opinions are like the airforce one: everybody got one.
Ok guys, lets keep the things clean and try to keep good habits in future, both for the person asking the question and the one answering the question.

Does anybody here have interest/experience in node.js development in IOT
IOT is just a generic marketing buzzword. It still involve regular development / programming stuff.
To clarify what I mean is backend service managing signals between items other than your computer and phone

Basically the signals are just HTTP or socket connections. So really it is just a bunch of HTTP / socket clients in many physical forms connecting to Node instances. They are not really that different from desktop or mobile HTTP clients.  Generally ,just expose the service end points with Node and code the client side to consume the services. IOT is just a meaningless term to describe pervasive connectivity of different things to the internet.

Hello guys..
I'm using node.js to build small online stock market.. 

Whole concept should look like this:
Brokers will connect to stock market (using socket.io / FIX / etc..) send stock orders. 

Stock market will accept orders (add to order list) and in interval it will process order list and send results back to brokers.

Naive solution is to use socket.io and setInterval to make stock server work. 

BUT..  it is not scalable nor cool

Do you have any idea, how to make it as much scalable as it can be?
why not do it immediately?

you can't trade after each request - there can be thousand requests each second

So it is processed in intervals..

And second thing, there can be more companies to trade with. It should run matching algorithm in intervals for each company.
Try redis with socketio, this helps the application to be scalable.
redis is fine .. but I cant imagine, how to use it in this situation

Jan Jůna node.js and socket.io by themselves made for the realtime application. You don't need to worry about these scalability, or worry about thousand of requests. Interval... it's not realtime so you don't need to user node.js also, just a raw javascript is enough, don't waste the most usage from node.js.
Btw, my current project serve for about 600 requests/s with only 1 virtual machine for node.js server and the CPU usage is just 10-20%, one more dedicate server for redis(take a look at redis pub/sub, it give you a hand for making damn good realtime messaging system), if you have more Memory you can use them both in one server but not recommended for the high-available and fault tolerant!

but how it shoud look like, when I add server? Or when I use node.js cluster module.. 

I thought, that I will make several nodes that will write requests to monodb and 1 or more nodes, which will take company, read its requests, process them and write results back.

On first nodes, the will read results from DB and transfer them to brokers via socket.io

What do you think about this concept?

Jan Jůna you dont need to worry about the thousand of requests. Everything is process in a single thread in an evented way. For running matching algorithms, create Connect Middlewares so you can process a single request in a sequence of middleware chains.
sorry I don't really understand your last message Jan Jůna
Load Balance multiple Node.js instances with Nginx with sticky sessions. Just broadcast the response to brokers clients in the anonymous function on DB save events. No need to read the DB again.

Im trying to take advantage of multicore servers.. So Id like to make more node.js servers (server A with connected brokers 1,2,3 and server B with brokers 4,5,6)

Then broker 6 send SELL request for google company to server B

Broker 1 send BUY request for google to server A

And now I dont know, how to connect these 2 requests.. First thought is to make 1 central server, which will be connected to A and B and will recieve all requests for google company.

It will process matching algorithm and then give back results of trades.. 

In normal market, there can be more than hundred of thousands requests per second so I would like to benefit of more threads/servers/clusters

Have you looked at Socket.IO docs? you don't need to strongly couple your brokers with your servers its a bad practice and not scalable at all. Just code up Node.js server with BUY and SELL API that takes company name / code for argument together with other details. All these requests goes through an Nginx load balancer that distributes the requests in a sticky manner to multiple instances of node.js server in a single machine. For matching algorithm, in the route handler attach Connect Middlewares to create a process chain that will process any number of algorithms that you want for the  request sequentially.

Blizzx Dita - but I need to pair orders from all node.js servers in interval.. so even with loadbalancer it is not solution - it will just server requests to node.js servers.. but these servers must gather all requests for company and somewhere process matching algorithm.. 

Sorry.. I don't get it.. how connect middleware helps me to gather all requests to one place?

Okay I get what you are trying to do now. Let say a SELL request comes in, you need to check whether there is matching BUY in the DB first. If there is none, write the SELL request with status flag AVAILABLE. Then let say another BUY request comes in, it will find any matching SELL requests with AVAILABLE flags on. If there is none write it immediately in the DB with status flag UNMATCH. Still you just need the same instances of Nodes across the machine no need to designate specific server for specific brokers. Not sure why you need the intervals enforced? can you explain?

These "order matching" algorithms works in intervals, because they count "strike price" from all orders.. They take orders, matches them with best price and process orders.

Example how order matching works is here:
http://market.dreamware.cz/order-matching

By the way, this is diploma thesis, so I must follow common rules, how this works..

I think what you need is a service. This service will perfom queries, run algorithms and execute orders in intervals.
So you have the following setup:
1) Clients->Node Servers(BUY n SELL Placements)->DB
2) DB->Node Order Server->Clients

The display page will connect to Node Order Server using socket.io
The SELL and BUY action page will connect to Node SELL and BUY server using socket.io or they can link to all the servers in one page happily

maybe it will be faster if I join Node Servers and Node order server too.. 

and DB will be there only for logging and for case of failure

Thank you guys for your ideas..

It wont be faster since you still need to enforce the intervals. The results wont return immediately after initial request. Be careful running interval service on the same server with buy and sell placement. It might block if it is CPU bound. Good luck
Many thanks :-)

Just go for it and worry about scaling later. Think of the user experience first. No point losing sleep with regards to scale if you don't even know if you will have any users at all. Premature optimization is the root of all bieberz.

data.message: i tried sail js but somehow i am more comfortable with express :)
express is awesome and for out of the box applications is excellent, total flexibility
what´s also not unimportant: express is kind of the standard thing, so there are some good books already and lots of information on that crazy little thing called internet.
yeah and express is the base of the "modern" or full stack frameworks, but for something more specific or more agile development frameworks like sails are very interesting
I tried to create a website with sails. It is good but still in development. In my opinion, sails will be powerful in near future
But express isnt Realtime app framework as Sails which provides out of box websocket/socket.io wrapper. Building realtime apps is the main benefit in node in my opinion
I prefer hapi.js from the guys at Wallmart because it's faster and it's really api oriented, i am done with mvc web applications :D, moving to SPA.
Even with SPA you should still have some kind of model and view separation on the client
yeah, you cannot really compare SPA to MVC... you can create SPAs with or without MVC.

That's true Andreas Teufel. My point is that, data backing up SPA application is best represented as models like User,Car etc. SPA without separation of model and view components can get hairy pretty quickly if the app gets more complex.
MVC is not cool anyway. angularjs uses MVW (model view whatever) :)
As long as data is not entangled in view and tightly coupled to individual element  its good to use whatever is appropriate The rest are just semantics.

data.message: I am curious, why do you guys use Node instead of things like Symfony? Because its hip? Because you hate PHP? Because its performance ?
Why do you use symfony instead of django? Ruby on rails? Zend framework? Play framework? C#/MVC?
being able to use javascript in both client and server programming + easiness of realtime apps (socket.io). Even without node.js I wouldn't want to use PHP, I feel it's a broken language in general
Florian Margaine: I ask you
No, yes, yes
Just compare a rails app to a Symphony app and the readability of the code is 500* clearer
So you use Rails and not Node?
I like the fact that it is JS, Which is like huge benefit being able to write client and server side codes in just JS>
I for one don't like JS at all, but the fact that it's an event driven design from the ground up makes it extremely suitable for certain use case scenarios, like IO bound web services
isn't about .php, is about I/O
All of above..!

Agree with Erik regarding merits of event driven design. For the same reasons node is particulary suitable for real time applications which are becoming more and more common across all domains. Take a look at http://blog.mixu.net/2011/02/01/understanding-the-node-js-event-loop/ for a more elaborate explanation. Also there are very valid reasons to dislike php : http://me.veekun.com/blog/2012/04/09/php-a-fractal-of-bad-design/ Not that javascript doesn't have it's quirks but once you get over closures and prototypal inheritence model, it is very consistent syntactically. Also from a business owner perspective using the most popular language in existence reduces technical debt. The node core libraries are well designed and are intuitive, behave predictably and fail in ways that can be handled in a sane fashion.

Hi,"PHP is broken language in general?" What the hell you are talking about. We got multiparadigmatic language over here, if we talking about PHP, we can do OOP [ORM] with PHP, we got lot of frameworks, open source projects, free CMS also. Facebook has build on PHP. We got Drupal, Joomla or Wordpress.  Looking forward for PHP6. Okay. Server-side Javascript is fine. I like node.js,, a like that 'Google´s V8 interpret cool phenomen', but preffer PHP, because of cheap hosting, community, history, lot of developers. Okay, I see, there are 'better' languages like Python and Ruby. But, I dont think that, the PHP is the lost way.

Anyway Symfony2 is fine, did you hear about Laravel? Also interesting project.
David Myšák it's my personal preference not to use it, but I don't think I am the only one with this opinion: http://me.veekun.com/blog/2012/04/09/php-a-fractal-of-bad-design/

I don't mind PHPs design.  But having used the overbuilt symphony I'd take almost anything over it.  I liked Codeigniter OK and Yii is probably my overall favorite for rapid dev frameworks in PHP.  But even though i'm new to node I can develop higher quality stuff faster in it than those frameworks that I knew better because it is already more mature from a productivity standpoint.  The fact that it also has way better performance, is more intuitive, and has support for... basically eveyrthing is just icing.

I mean I built my own custom web crawler in like ... 3 hours.  How long would that take in symphony?  would that even make sense?  Node and it's various plugins/packages make it like a bunch of magic web development legos.

- performance test Node.JS vs PHP:
http://blog.loadimpact.com/2013/02/01/node-js-vs-php-using-load-impact-to-visualize-node-js-efficency/

- ruby on rails vs Node.JS (linkedin has reduced 27 of 30 servers when he moved to node)
http://highscalability.com/blog/2012/10/4/linkedin-moved-from-rails-to-node-27-servers-cut-and-up-to-2.html

- and it brings us much more possibilities, what we can do .. eg. realtime apps like chats, games, push notifications,.. etc

- nonblocking architecture is also nice thing

- same code in front end, back end and even database too

- and the last one.. it's cool as hell

as for bad design of php. I disagree.  It's just weird.  There are two types of languages: those people complain about, and those nobody uses.  PHP gets used for a lot for a reason: it's easy and its design scales horizontally pretty well by default.  Also, without threads you can use all the typical single-threaded design patterns easily.  It means that junior-medium programmers can be very productive.  If the worst you get is a bunch of weird syntax (that's still not TOO bad), then that's ok.

It's also purpose built for the web.  Not a lot of other languages have things like mysql_real_escape_string(), etc, that just solve a problem for you built in.  Once again - it's all about productivity.  Performance only matters AFTER you've managed to get popular.  If nobody comes to your site it doesn't matter what it's built on.

I am a php developer from structured to mvc programming. I do sites using php for my clients. When I am planning to develop my own startup, i was thinkng like, can php scale? 

I did a lot of reseach and php is not an ideal language for a scalable site. Yeah, FB is created with PHP, but they are using "hiphop" which compiles php codes to C++ code to make the site faster. 

Some of the answers are already above. Another reason is that, I have no time to learn ruby/rails or django, I already know JS, but the approach is a bit different. the new Myspace is built with Express. So i am confident that nodejs can handle sites with heavy traffic.
Why Symfony?

I do not know of a single valid reason to ever choose php besides 'I only know php' or 'we are working with php legacy code so we don't have an option'. I'd honestly love to hear one and then specifically mention something that php is better suited for than any other option.
"I want to build a site that's cheap and there are tons of free CMS/ecommerce/blog systems built on top of PHP that perfectly fit our needs and allow us to use less expensive labor"

that is exactly what erik refers to by 'we are working with php legacy code so we don't have an option'. it might be true that nodejs doesnt have those kind of mature platforms yet, but maybe it's because php is almost 20 years old
I love node.js!  I wonder what this means for Java.
who is java
Because it confuses you. That's why.

socket.io question
has anyone tried to emit a message from the server NOT in the "connection" event?
like pushing a message to the client without him asking...
(when an event happens in the server that has nothing to do with the client, but i want to notify the client about it)

I think io.sockets.emit is what you're looking for. You can use it wherever you have the reference to io.sockets. Additionally if you want to emit to a specific user or users you can store the references from the the connect event by a non-local variable or create rooms (https://github.com/LearnBoost/socket.io/wiki/Rooms).

check out some basic node.js tutorials, it´s very important to know how module loading works and part of pretty much every beginners tutorial.
Why cant you use npm on the servers?
maybe he does not want to install it. not needed anyway, because you should never update directly on the live server. better to update on dev and test it, then deploy.

just avoiding too many npm module install..
if folder means just copy and paste

But using npm would make user errors alot less frequent.
Do you use any type of deploy tool? Or do you just ftp all files up?

If you use any tool, just add a 'npm install' run to the list of tasks.
rsync is good for deployment, for example. calling npm on the live server is very bad imho...what user errors are you talking about?
Yes rsync is good for deployment for using many server..for now am using ftp for deplyment

Every extra step a user have to do during deploy increases the rate of user errors.
Calling npm on live servers might be bad but is it better to sync up a couple of thousand files?
Automatisation is (if done right) a great thing, using a tool like capistrano for depolyment and set up tests to make sure that everything runs as it should, before changing the symlink to the new source folder, is, in my opinion, better than manually upload every file with a ftp client or even using rsync. The more automated something is (and ofcourse tested) the less risk of errors due to user there is.

actually, not using npm on the live server would even be less steps ;) - because you need a deployment with rsync or ftp anyway. rsync is VERY fast, that´s no problem. rsync is not really manual, of course you have to trigger the deployment manually (in every case) but then it´s 100% automated. it´s not like you build your rsync call every time you deploy, you can put it in a deploy script and stuff. rsync is pretty powerful, you know.

You set up your deploy script once, then you just run it.

Personally i dont use rsync or ftp, but git and npm, works like a charm, and as long as the new installation is done in a seperate directory and then set as current codebase its very safe, also opens up for very quick rollbacks if nessesery (as long as you dont rm the old dirs).

Anything that works, works, not gonna try to convert anyone here, hehe. But I would recommend not using FTP for this tho, it will end up making the deployment take ALOT more time than it have to! :)

modyle / module.exports to zwykle obiekty, nie ma wiecej zadnej filozofii :P trzeba tylko wiedziec co to przekazywanie przez referencje

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Talk:JavaScript/Guide/Obsolete_Pages/Defining_Functions

it doesn't help to know about references if you don't know how the variables come into scope and where they reference to. node brings exports into scope as reference to module.exports and this is what the post is about.
if it helps someone to get a grip on references vs. values I'm happy too.

Still the simplest explanation is that module is a global object (like window in the browser) in terms of a node instance. module.exports is a sub-object and exports is a reference to module.exports. But you're right - scoping is important here, and showing how you can easily break things by swapping the build-in references can save beginners a lot of headaches :)

data.message: I know this is only partially node-related, but since front-end frameworks are so commonly paired with node, I figured this is my best shot at getting several perspectives (Stack Overflow hates open-ended questions like this). Anyway, has anyone paired Socket.io with a Javascript MV* framework, and gotten server-push working well? I am looking for a framework that would work well with atypical SPAs, as in not just basic CRUD apps (to be specific, real-time PBBGs). I have to say I have just not liked Angular so far, but it is on my list to work with more down the line. I guess the 2 main ones I am reviewing are Backbone and Ember, but am also open to more suggestions if there is something else that would meet my needs well. Both BB and Ember have Socket.io modules, but they are fairly small and I don't know how well they are supported. Thank you!

It would be a bonus if I may end up coming across professional work in the framework as well, so as nice as rAppid.js may be, for example, I probably wouldn't go that way since the experience would likely be of little benefit professionally.

have a look on polvo the compiler we use to build our sites. the compiler holds a socket.io server which is used to do live devlopment and its ready for a tweak that would allow pushing among other features.
We are already working on its new version that will expose all hooks so you will be able to do it without touching the core. Weare willing to give you an introduction if you need. search "github polvo"
Looks interesting. But is this a client-side framework? It is hard for me to tell from the README what this actually is

its a build system, you can build either client or server side. the compiler is a http server and socket server which  comes already with "live reload" for css/js/html when in dev mode.

you would just extend the server for your extra needs, like pushing code or any other thing. not saying its your ideal solution, its just an option in case you would feel comfortable working on something in your way ( just fork and go ahead )
Oh, OK. Looking over it again I got a better feel for it. Interesting. I will keep it in mind!

How do u deal with foreign characters like hindu, japanese, korean, hebrew in mysql db? 

I know this can be done by adding/setting utf8_general_ci for each table u did but do i need to convert mysql compatible text format  or just insert whatever character it is to the db?

utf8_general_ci is just collation rule. It does not actually collate by language collation rules (that particular one). Content (data) is content - you shall decide how you want to be stored (encoded or not). Usually default depends on a unicode support that programming language use and obviously what mysql will understand by what you have sent.

this could help: 

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3328968/how-can-i-store-unicode-in-mysql

It's really magical.

data.message: is it really a MUST for a complex site to have an ORM like sequelize? I feel like I am more comfortable to use the plain or basic mysql method than orm.
Yes, it's a must. You will waste a lot of time on writing things that are already implemented in Sequelize. Also: security concerns. And what if you want to change DBMS?

In my humble opinion, It would depend on the direction of your project and what the immediate union current needs are.

Check this article out.
http://sigpwned.com/content/should-i-use-orm-or-not-sure
my heart is still 50/50 -______________-
DRY
well, i don't think we're here to convince you, you do whatever you want with your project, we're are just giving advice!!!

Nah, im already convinced actually. To think about it, expressjs is a webframework to make ur job faster.. while sequelize is an ORM to make ur dbms faster.so there's no point   for doing the old school way.. :3 thanks everyone :3
yup, its simply easier to use sequelize.....
aha! ORM for Node. I asked before as I was looking for some good ORM for node.

There are reasons to use raw SQL.  Some things sequelize just can't do.  But you can still run raw queries on sequelize and use the ORM for everything else.  That way if you have to refactor/change DBs you only have to deal with those few queries that don't match.

On that note, if anyone knows how to do variable x is greater than A but less than B in sequelize or do a multiple join with sequelise (where table1.var = table2.var and table2.var =table3.var) etc. I'd love to know how
It's not a must. Raw SQL is faster than ORM. ORM is convenient. I am using sequelize which also allows raw SQL.
well an ORM use raw SQL, an ORM is just a series of functions that use SQL
ORMs are for "i whant my program to be available to anyone using any db system". If you write stuff for your own db system, write a service layer with or without it.
