Hello guys, Firs please tell me that can i ask some of the my questions here ? or not, there is not a place for asking questions.

If i can ask, so please answer my new question:

there is my first very simple app based on node, its better dont call it app, this is 3 menu that change the pages, but problem is here: when i click on the menus, the pages change fine, but the menus disappear for a moment  and then appear again when the new page load complete, i used fs module to load HTML pages content, but its seems to be slow, something is wrong there, it must not be like that, what is the problem ? why this delay happen ?
data.caption: Attachment UnavailableThis attachment may have been removed or the person who shared it may not have permission to share it with you.

data.message: you're using just fs module, and in my opinion it's not a good idea, i suggest you to use ExpressJS will help you a lot in your little application ;)

Hello Kourosh Sharifi. You are free to ask questions here, related to Node.js and Javascript. Better use Google before asking it here.

The problem with your app is that you are doing a full page reload with each click on the menu, which is leading to disappearing of menu for a short time. You need some kind of view mechanism so that your menu stays there at the top all the time, and just the body content changes when a menu is clicked. 

For that you need to look at client side libraries such as Angular, Backbone etc.
If that overwhelms you, then try Sammy.js [ http://sammyjs.org ]
Is anybody else aware of some server-side solution for partial loading of page?
don't ask to ask ...

Okay, Nice, But i used PHP file_get_contents to simulate this app with PHP and this issue not happen anymore, is this problem about fs module ? or it related to the Node ? what if i dont want to use any framework like backbone or Express ?

Its not a problem with fs module or node, its just how web apps are done. Instead of reloading the full page, just a part of page is loaded. 

And what you are trying to achieve is possible without using Node. If you are not using any frameworks, you'll be reinventing the wheel.

I just to try comparing PHP file_get_content and Node fs module, PHP file_get_content and Node fs module is no partial either, so    why this issue happen is Node fs Module but not happen in PHP ? This my question.
Your assets are not wired properly in your node app. That might be the reason.
also, why file_get_content? that´s not comparable to what you are doing in node, because it´s meant to parse external links. also, curl is better/faster than file_get_content.

slow is because apache handle your css & js in php your browser most likely cached the all your assets from your first request, other than that apache may do gzip, server side cached. in your node app you need to code to serve the file (you have not done that). manually serving static files you should at the very least use streams to pipe to response.

see how others do it http://ejohn.org/blog/node-js-stream-playground/

express.js use send to handle static files https://github.com/visionmedia/send

Would really appreciate if someone could help.

What is diffrence between request.url and url.parse.(request.url).pathname ?

req.url includes both the path and the query string while url.parse(request.url).pathname will only contain the path without the query string

Eg.

url  -  /hello/1/3/4?a=b&x=y
req.url  -  /hello/1/3/4?a=b&x=y
url.parse(req.url).pathname  -  /hello/1/3/4

i would say it is probably better to server static files, imgs etc using nginx as it is way quicker, and proxy api requests to node instances running on a separate port(s) that way you don't need to be root and run node on port 80
ghost.org and the new myspace.com are using nodejs..
I do not know if nginx is faster necessarily. I believe most benchmarks show nodejs tied if not higher, especially if clustered.
What benchmarks?

I mean, you can google it if you would like. There are results going both ways; some even say Apache wins (whaaaaat?)

So, take it with a grain of salt. I believe Ryan Dahl shows some benchmarks in his release almost 4 years ago that show them being comparable with Node having the edge (though I admit I have not watched this video in some time) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M-sc73Y-zQA
I believe it's quite common to proxy requests through nginx on production. I hear everyone do that so there must be a reason and I think performance is not the most important thing here. :)

I really meant strictly for static assets such as images. You can cache them in memory with node but its not very efficient. I have experienced this definitely, however I do not have any benchmarks. In my use case it was a difference between milliseconds and over a second. 

You could certainly use node to cache template strings; that would still be quick; but lots of large images in binary/base64 would store a minimum of the file size in memory and slow down your server from handling lighter requests.
By clustering you would get a quicker response from serving raw files, as you could have 2+ processors serving disc reads (or writes) and using streams would allow better concurrency, however the response of one file streaming to synchronous would be slower in a direct 1-to-1 comparison.

In reality there are a lot of factors involved in this and every one use-case/situation is different. It really depends on what you are trying to achieve in your project, how many visitors you expect your site/app to get, how many static assets you will be serving, the size of those assets and what hardware resources your server has and/or is available.

If it is just a small site/prototype with small to medium traffic it will really not make a huge difference.

With regards to proxying there is not much difference between putting nginx in front of node and using nginx/apache with php or ruby/python with passenger. The only difference is that with php i've not heard of people running a php server on port 80 without nginx or apache, where as with node this is easy and common.
Also I might add if you do use nginx in front of node and your node process goes down nginx can handle the response to your user more gracefully.

hi guys! I have no problem with timestamp or something. here is the problem, 
>Llet's say. I am from the Philippines, you re from India, and someone from US. 
> The default timezone, lets say America/New York. now is 2:27pm / new york is 2:27am / india is 10am for example. 

> I posted a status at 2:27pm / but it will be saved in New York timezone

> the site will display the post in PH timezone. that mean, the site automatically convert the NY timestamp to PH timestamp

> if I move to...let's say Italy, the site will be automatically convert it to italian timezone

> the site will detect user's  timezone using jquery on frontend side...
Save it as UTC. :-)
ive read an article from somewhere, UTC is recommended..

Save it as UTC, and then record user's time zone for each user. In this way all records can be shown calculated in each user local time. Some databases will even help you with that.

This is also highly recommended when (if, but more likely when) you hit daylight saving problems with time.

Even more mature systems have problems with DST.

So UTC it.

I have spent some time pondering of various chat scenarios and played with node sockets, and came to main conclusion here. Main considerations would be:

How that chat would look like?

There are 3 different approaches in sense of making application:
1. command line
2. desktop web based application (e.g. node+webkit)
and of course
3. web based app (runs in standard browser)

Second how this chat will work?

1. centrally connected
2. peer to peer
3. mix of above two

of course a server considerations in central model (node or something else including web and messaging).

Once the model is decided, then approach can be selected. (even then there are some doubts, for example I did came to number of discussions on the line Socket.IO or WebSockets or sockjs or ????)

Simple wish - not a simple task.

actually, yes, that is exactly what socket.io is doing indeed > falling back to ajax polling
I want browsers to be connected with 'websocket' finanlly not 'ajax'.
you know, if the browser does not support websockets, then there is no websockets. obviously.

ah, sorry. i misread your answer...lol...well, you could use an entry page for that.
ok. I'll try. thanks :)

Have you tried configuring your transports? Socket.io has fallback transports, xhr-polling is what I think does what you described:

io.set('transports', [
  'websocket'
  , 'flashsocket'
  , 'htmlfile'
  , 'xhr-polling'
  , 'jsonp-polling'
]);

https://github.com/LearnBoost/Socket.IO/wiki/Configuring-Socket.IO

Arbie Samong I've tried just. but this way haven't worked OK.

I changed like this.

io.set('transports', [
    'xhr-polling'     <<< I changed the order.
  , 'websocket' <<< -
  , 'flashsocket'
  , 'htmlfile'
  , 'jsonp-polling'
  ]);

at first, browsers are connected with 'xhr-polling' OK. but that's all!
It doesn't try to connect with websocket again.
of course not, it takes the first one that is supported. try using an entry page with ajax and redirect to a page with socket, what about that? i am not sure if you can switch manually.
Andreas Teufel OK. now, I'm considering that a module for this doesn't exist. So I think I should try manually. but I'm a beginner. anyway I'll try again it you said above. thanks for advising me. :)
How about two instances? One with xhr poll configured and another with websocket. Or see if you can reconfigure after some time

Appologize to intrude, I would like to learn something here too ;) So

It looks to me that webSockets (that would be W3C spec) is not ready yet (and will not be ready for some time). Second if that is not ready there is choice, so far I understand there is quite talked about SocketIO but I also stepped onto Sockjs that would be intermediate work for Web sockets. Also unlike PUSH to client method (as main driver for socketio and sockjs), we have PULL from server method (ajax) + security limitations on a browser side.

Now, I see sockjs is already some 2 years old, while socketio is still under some debate. Where do we stand today with w3c and these two? Is it worth jumping in now? And which one to choose? (maybe this shall be separate topic)

iirc socket.io now takes care of that automagically . PS network delay will take time (In no real world scernario websocket can be slower then xhr-comet), you can rather send the first packet as json [something like sails.js] and then wait till u establish connection using websockets.

Actually to be accurate this shall be the logic:

127.0.0.1/localhost - you bind your listening to localhost only (this is good protection if your system shall work on  1 cpu-box and internally e.g. your web server talks to your database but you do not want that someone else outside make connection to the database meaning out of local cpu-box, your database will listen to localhost and web server to world)

your ip - you listen to the world but only on the interface that has that IP address. This is fine solution only caveats there would be: if you have more than one interface, other interfaces are not listened to, second, if you move your code to another cpu-box with another IP you need to change the code, and of course IP that changes breaks your web application (eg DHCP).

listening to 0.0.0.0 says: listen to all local interfaces all IP - basically listen to all incoming traffic.

Maybe you shall read some networking books there is plenty of documentation on IP protocols on the net.

so if i create 2 servers then using my ip in the listen() would work for only 1? 0.0.0.0 looks a better option then...one more thing-are there any security issues with this method?(i.e. can i get hacked? :P)

Sorry but I did not understand your question (first part).

Second part: listening to 0.0.0.0 is nothing to do with being vulnerable to hacking. Your app is weak point for hacking not interface you are listening to. Listening to 0.0.0.0 simply says - listen to all incoming traffic on your cpu-box (PC) - this is simply socket specification (assumed network mask is also 0.0.0.0)

If you wish to make app that works only in intranet you'd need to filter out some traffic - ie detect corresponding IP and allow/refuse connection (this is why node is not the same as web servers). In apache web server you can configure to listen only to a set of external IP's (eg 192.168.0.0/255.255.255.0 apache will respond only to other PCs with IP's 192.168.0.0 - 192.168.0.255 but will not listen/will refuse connection for example from 192.168.1.x) in node you have to write that filter for yourself (sorry no shortcuts or easy solutions)

To be honest I never tried to experiment with node sockets, maybe it is possible to specify IP/netmask in some way. If it is possible then you can limit listening to allowed set of IP's, but generally speaking allow/deny comes on top of socket (i.e. it is later logical security layer built in your application)

http://nodejs.org/api/net.html#net_class_net_server

server.listen(port, [host], [backlog], [callback])#
Begin accepting connections on the specified port and host. If the host is omitted, the server will accept connections directed to any IPv4 address (INADDR_ANY). A port value of zero will assign a random port.
------

this above is section from node.js reference, note situation that you can omit 'host' in that case you listen INADDR_ANY this is the same as saying server.listen(port,'0.0.0.0') with 0's you are just being specific.

now I understand why there is so much talk about node socket. There are but very few examples. Its worth writing an article explaining what happens in some basic communication, when and how. I tried to write a simple unix pipe type of socket and have run into a number of doubts.

On the other hand, Node sockets are actually very simple socket implementation no big and complicated stuff.

Hi there.. My tasks run and the files exists in this folder that i am reading from..
But why dont they get into the destination.. thanks..
um... dafuq is regexp? You do know that ECMAScript comes with regexp matchin in native String objects right? https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt-contrib-copy can get you further here I think

aah. !!!.. I could do that but this code in another large plugin.. i just made up a small one out of it to test it independently.. 
btw why doesnt it get piped to destination is what I am concerened..!!
btw u cant rename files using that plugin, Stefan Staudenmeyer..

First of all, piping from a source to a destination file is exactly the same as copying.

Then, piping is an asynchronous process. Your node process probably quits before the piping has finished.

Grunt tasks are by defaults synchronious, if you want an async task to run (piping is async), you need to call this.async() inside the task, which gets you a callback function you can use to notify Grunt the task is done.

add something like this at the end:
dest.on("end",this.async());

note that this will, obviously, only work for a single file, you'll need to do more complicated async logic to support multiple file pipes  (you'll need to join the async threads and then call the this.async() method on the last async thread, try using the npm module async)

You will need some kind of hardware to interface between the computer and the robotics/home hardware you want to automate, but there are so many guides and articles on that search, it must be possible.

What could be worse than Web developers not knowing how to escape callback hell? Operating systems or proprietary hardware venous ;)

I know that there are other controllers you can buy that can plug into a regular PC, and that way you could bypass the Arduino. I just figured from the coding perspective, those links would have info on how to start doing it with node. I think people just get into the Arduino because it is so small and can create a self-contained system. But I agree, having to hook up the PI with an Arduino is a bit overboard unless you already happen to have both.

Tim Crouch i know, PC controllers are not new they are present in control systems for years. But again you'd need some (and sometime significant) electronic knowledge to be able to interface with sensors/controllers. Lego IMHO went furthest of all, making it easy to combine - but it is a toy.

Somewhere in end of 90ties and beg of 2000 there was a project that sounded interesting yet to my knowing it never picked up after that initial spin. There was a robot with a pc inside and all hardware was there including sensors - just add software... it was standard PC and you could program in anything that is available on a standard PC. Lot of promises and then - nothing. Seems that people already went other way with interests.

Arduino and PI are two (for me) very interesting offers that appeared recently (third are some z machines offering PC on a stick). They have their niches as very small computers you can do interesting things, experiment,  or use in education (as they are comparatively very cheap to a proper comp).

Back to original subject This node os i something that could be very small yet capable, so Pi would be possible target (do not know how you'd run it on arduino because of its lack of multitasking). For sure I would not run node os on a PC unless it is some small transportable pc with limited resourses.

Using full PC to run home automation or robot is a bit of an overkill for me.

Chrome OS is in my view amiss. However if they just added a local web server and a database to that machine it could be full platform that you could do interesting stuff offline and online. Chrome OS as is it is just Google advertising kiosk. Very few people will opt to use it or will use it in special circumstances. IMHO wrong or incomplete way of doing things.

Stefan Staudenmeyer care to elaborate ? (on What could be worse than Web developers not knowing how to escape callback hell? Operating systems or proprietary hardware venous )

IMHO node is better for non-web but somehow web picked up there. Node would much more shine in robotics and control systems. Once upon a time Forth was choice of robotic systems but it did not have multitasking abilities.
The amount of processes you'd need to fork just to get the OS up is (I guess) enormous. I mean, it's still single threaded...
I agree with  Tim Crouch but I think npm packages don't enough ..

Stefan Staudenmeyer (guessing from little public info) its linux kernel, so i presume there is a set of deamons like in basic linux installations. It does not seem to me this will have any graphics (or GUI), so whole system could be very small, actually much smaller than some OSes for mobile phones. Node has relatively small runtime (so it may be multiplied), also I guess it shall have some C compiler otherwise it would be tricky to add significant library functionality. I am curious how it looks like but I do not believe it will be very large nor it would have a lot of processes. I remember times when I run Linux on 8MB RAM (no it is not error, it was just early linux :) )

It is possibly too early to tell what this node-os will be. Maybe Tim Crouch is right, possible target for this could be PI (now this looks like very plausible idea). At least I would like to see it on PI (that would take away platform support)

Or maybe to run it as virtual.

nodejs can be vulnerable to an injection of javascript?
SuperLike! Very Valuable point for contemplation.
If you just eval "untrusted" json then this is a vector of attack.
eval is evil. just saying.
so how to make ur node app secured?
use brain instead of eval
experience and common sense?, i agree with Ljubisa Gavrilovic
Ljubisa Gavrilovic why would someone want to eval JSON when it can be parsed? or both are same?

My early post was just loud thinking. 
And no - they are not the same (eval & parsing)

JSON like structure is chosen because it directly translates to data facilities (structures) of javascript language and shall be possible to be eval-ed to internal values. In fact in early days of javascript prior to appearance of JSON it was quite common to use pieces of code as data structure and communicate it over the net and someone may use this technique today as very convenient and powerful. You'd simply eval such code (this is possible because javascript is interpreted language)

AFAIK (not in much detail) there was number of protocols that could pass a functions (methods) together with the data. Today we are discouraged to do that because of potential security attack vectors. But in early days of OO idea of exchanging objects over the net (not only data but also a functionality) was very strong only to be discovered later that this is not very wise approach to do if you do not control whole system. BUT it is still very powerful concept of computing. 

Think of it as callback functions that are not in code but sent over internet. There is a lot of possible uses for such approach.

In a way I miss not having passing 'methods' in JSON but that can be implemented as for example a set of library functions.

Parsing is different technique and applies to structured data processing (as textual data). Eval is equivalent to execution. These are two completely different approaches to processing the data.
I often wander if JSON parsers are actually secure.

just a bit more on eval (came to my mind later when thinking of parsers). If you do eval you are reusing built-in javascript language parser instead of using JSON parser (that may be implemented in js code or as binary). I could bet that eval is much faster in parsing.

data.message:
The process of "zipping" a file refers to putting it into an archive format such as "ZIP." This compresses the file, making it smaller. You can compress several files into a single ZIP archive, making them easier to store and transfer over email as the files are smaller, and they can be moved by just moving that one ZIP file.

To know more on how you can zip files in node.js, read our blog:
http://www.intelligrape.com/blog/2014/01/29/working-with-zip-files-in-node-js/

My question is whether I start with SQL or just jump straight into NoSQL like Mongodb?

I am a second year computer science student. I know C , C++, C#.Net ,html & javascript and learning nodejs

Honestly you will probably have to learn SQL for school, so you could get a jump on that. But schedule in some time to also get to know MongoDB. It won't take long to learn since it is so much more simple than SQL. Mongo is also a great fit for node.
if you want to take it serious, you will have to learn both.
i will learn both ,but i want to ask that is it necessary to first learn SQL ?
thanks Tim Crouch
mongo ftw

I think you should learn first SQL then when you have learned the concepts of relational databases, you could learn noSQL databases such as mongoDB. As others told you, it wont take to much time to learn mongodb.
Mongodb has different approach to relational databases.
You might also want to take a look at this site:
https://class.coursera.org/db 
and last: https://education.mongodb.com/ 
for me the best place to learn mongoDB.
thankyou Carlos Carcamo :)

Learn SQL first, no doubt. I hate to say it, but if you learn Mongo first, you will be screaming in your head "Why is all of this complication needed?!" when learning SQL. Plus, even though Mongo is NoSQL, having a good understanding of the kinds of things you may need to query in SQL will actually help you design better Mongo databases. It is also doubtful your school will teach Mongo, as most universities have not created a curriculum for NoSQL, so learn first what will directly help you in school. But follow it up with Mongo. It is awesome!
before you learn sql or nosql, learn about mathematical sets. All databases emanate from set mathematics. Once you understand sets you will understand sql select/join and nosql map/reduce.

Use an ORM....know SQL basics, but no need to master it unless u want to become a DBA.

In nodejs... At least for basic uses, LOTS are similar when u look at mongoose vs sequelize (both ORMs. For nosql and SQL)
Different story if ur actually someone that wants to join in orm development....but for most cases its quite fine to just use orm

i couldn't say which is better, but I got fluent in mysql and php before even touching node.  I've used nosql a bit and it doesn't feel as neat at mysql, but it is more restrictive.  i'd say just do 2 projects and use one on each, then decide for yourself.
SQL first. When there are problems you cannot solve with SQL, then you go NoSQL.
Learn SQL first
Hello. I am still learning Express and I have a question. How do u clean the POST data from the form? like removing html tags, converting characters to mysql-compatible data, and so on...

you could try to use some middleware for that, like:

app.use(express.bodyParser());

and then in your handler, use req.body object (here are some more details on that http://expressjs.com/api.html#req.body)

Now, assuming you send ?foo=bar, you would access that like this: req.body.foo

Cheers! :D
app.use(express.bodyParser()); <---this line where i always see that i dont even know what the heck this was XD , does the cleaning job?
ok,ill read that.. :D multumesc! :D
I see. :3 #noted :D

Actually sending ?foo=bar is a query parameter.

If your route is registered as app.post('/users/:name') and you make a POST request with data { "age": 23 } to this url: /users/john?nickname=johnny

You get:
req.params.name => "john"
req.body.age => 23
req.query.nickname => "johnny"

I'm pretty sure that if you don't have the content-type:application/json setup in the right place, age will not be available.
Anyway, the bodyParser middleware knows how to abstract data (name/ value pairs, JSON body and multipart) and it all ends up in req.body.

Leandro Ostera: what you've written is a combination of named placeholders, GET parameters (or query parameter as you've called it) and a JSON body.

You seem to be quite an opinionated guy.

A part of me really wants to understand why you open a modern editor in an old operating system and expect it to work like a charm. It's like trying to run Node on Windows. At the end, it's far better to fire up a VM with a decent UNIX-like.

The other part of me really wants to punch you in the face for not catching up. :)

I am opinionated :) yes. I figured that during answering to you, opinions come from experience.... (especially bad experience)

You see I like pick my tools slowly and pick them because they are good, not because they are cool. My tools are working and would not give up in critical times. 

I love to see new things. I like cool things. But more than often I would go back to old tool if it is more stable and trustworthy. But I will support new things if they are good. New OSXes are not (going too much to the IOS way - that is bad Apple move)

Whatever i do i try to do on more than one platform and environment and, yes, i use node on OSX and windows. Blasphemy blasphemy ;) Herecy :) :)

Now, there is something about sublime, it needs some consolidation - conceptual. It is likable, cool, hackery but not yet good, at least not for me.

At the end of the day node is hackery too. It is far from good tool yet. But it is ehm, innovative and promising. Has good vibe. Its javascript renaissance. Hope it stays that way (i am too long in software development - so long that I have seen languages crazes come and go) Javascript deserved some push - node was that push. I welcome it.

serverside javascript is not new thing (it was present in original netscape server (approx mid 90ties) and you could write server and client side in the same HTML) - unfortunately netscape server was never popular because it was too expensive.

Application side javascript is not new thing either there was MicrosoftScriptingHost with JScript (which was at its time extremely good implementation). But Microsoft did not put it because they wanted to make it good, but because it was fighting with Netscape at the time.

Do you design before programming?

I've just programed so far without designing, I'm always going through difficulty for maintenance.

Is there much difference I did or not?
Should I design first?

and is it OK to use mind-map tool for it?
Is always good to make a plan. It will be easier to maintain and reuse code for other projects. Less code repeated, the less chance of errors.
yes you should design first. even if it´s just on paper. and check out TDD (test driven development) too.
Of course, you should frigging design first! Even if it just thinking for an hour and drawing a picture on a napkin, design is essential.
David Gironella Casademont I can be sure by your favor. Thanks to answer for me. :)
Andreas Teufel ok! I'll do it from now on. I'll spend for designing even more much time. Thanks :)
David Tomlinson I haven't thought that it's not very important, but now I realized the importance of it. Thanks for your advice. :)
using mind-map tool can be useful. Design phase is very important, don't skip preparing user stories and design. Jumping into development without design isn't good thing to do.
Md Rezaur Rahman Ok. So far I've felt like going somewhere without the map for my destination. I didn't know what to do. So, I'll do it from on now. Thanks :)
btw.. is there any design tool like enterprise architect for node.js or JS? Something, what will generate basic structure of application, or do you write your code from scratch?
express ;) - or yeoman

ok.. same question - is there some graphic tool to generate express sculpture? :-P 

Something what will take UML and generate code..
Woah, UML? Get outta here.
nope, nothing like this out there as far as i know.
Jan Jůna Yeoman will help you to generate a basic working application.
thanks.. :-)
Learn and use Object Oriented Analysis and Modeling...  Write use cases and draw atleast class diagrams first.. Model your system..  It is essential...

That's like the worst advice to give someone. And unless you work in huge (millions of lines of code) Java applications, it's mostly useless to sit down and do all your UML homework.

Keep it simple. Go agile. Let the architecture emerge from your application and some guidelines. And ffs keep your inheritance as shallow as possible. Easier to get, easier to explain, easier to maintain.
A little amount of common sense and a pen and paper should do the job.

Design but do not over-design. Design where you need a design not everywhere. If you plan large maybe you shall design or better you may be better not going large. If you over-design you may be inflexibile.

See if you can conceptualize idea, then make a version. Try to be realistic. Almost always once you start using it you realize that we are rarely able to forecast real need in advance thus do not expect to guess everything in your design. I loved book from 37signals - these people really hit a nail.

In fact some really simple things became really large. Use twitter for example. In essence that is insanely conceptually simple system.
OK! I really realized that a design is very important. Thanks to your help!

Please help me write the solution for this problem from "Learnyounode" Tutorial .

This is the problem statement :

This problem is the same as the previous problem (HTTP COLLECT) in
that you need to use `http.get()`. However, this time you will be
provided with three URLs as the first three command-line arguments.

You must collect the complete content provided to you by each of the
URLs and print it to the console (stdout). You don't need to print out
the length, just the data as a String; one line per URL. The catch is
that you must print them out in the same order as the URLs are
provided to you as command-line arguments.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
HINTS:

Don't expect these three servers to play nicely! They are not going to
give you complete responses in the order you hope, so you can't
naively just print the output as you get it because they will be out
of order.

You will need to queue the results and keep track of how many of the
URLs have returned their entire contents. Only once you have them all,
you can print the data to the console.

Counting callbacks is one of the fundamental ways of managing async in
Node. Rather than doing it yourself, you may find it more convenient
to rely on a third-party library such as http://npm.im/async or
http://npm.im/after. But for this exercise, try and do it without any
external helper library.

The Previous problem

Write a program that performs an HTTP GET request to a URL provided to
you as the first command-line argument. Collect all data from the
server (not just the first "data" event) and then write two lines to
the console (stdout).

The first line you write should just be an integer representing the
number of characters received from the server and the second line
should contain the complete String of characters sent by the server.

How to install express framework On Windows ?

Install globally : npm install -g express
Instally locally :npm install express
(it will be installed inside node_modules)

You have two options.

1. Download Linux and install Node from repos, binaries, or source. Then install express using npm.

2. Open Internet Explorer, order a Mac, install using the installer or homebrew. Then install express using npm.

Hello Every1,

"Error: Can't set headers after they are sent."

How can I fix this error? 
Please let me know.

Thanks :)
Hastebin the code snippet if possible
That happens if you try to set a HTTP response header, even though you already ended the response. Like this: https://gist.github.com/saschagehlich/44f7b2c0b58dfd53e2f1
In your case the problem is in line 42. You are ending the response, even though the SQL query might not be done yet. Remove that line and it should work.

Now there is a 512 MB version for almost the same price. I use it and I'm happy about :) There are people out there which use several of them for a cluster. In this case you would be able to use 1x for the system and 1x for the database ;-)

Heroku is kind of slow if you go with a free plan. Try a VPS at first. Personally, I've used http://www.intovps.com/ , and it was very good (both services and support), and now I'm using http://digitalocean.com/ . DigitalOcean is cloud-based, and it's a good service. Both of these have a starter $5 plan, which for a single (or couple) of websites is more than enough ;)

The last two years I've been making a kind of programming competition platform called 'Escape from /dev/null' in node.js and client-side Dojo.

It's a system that has two parts; first it's a kind of web-based board-game where teams can choose to take on certain programming 'quests'. The second part is a live web-based API that the programming quests are targeting.

The web-based APIs are of different scenarios, one is a space survival and the other (current) is a multi-user rogue-like game where teams can (as part of the programming competition) create characters, solve problems and so forth.

https://www.facebook.com/EscapeFromdevnull?bookmark_t=page

I've coding Java for about seven years prior to learning JS (beginning in 2005) and I can easily say that I wouldn't have been able to do 1/10 of the system with a legacy lagnauge. very, very happy with node.js

What's the craziest system other people have cooked up with node.js?
data.name: Escape from /dev/null
data.description: Escape from /dev/null is a series of programming competitions, where each team solve small (but increasingly complicated) programming challenges to move ahead on a communal game-board.

Hi,  can nodeJS be used to build high performance, scalable web applications? What about nodejs frameworks? Do we have good mvc framework for nodejs? Given a choice among CodeIgniter(php framework)  , django,  ruby on rails,  grails and nodejs  which would be the best choice to build a scalable web application?  Why?

The most common approach that people take when building a Node app, is to use Node at the back-end for providing a REST API, talking to the database or third-party services and then use a client side MV* framework such as Backbone, Angular etc. to consume that API. Most of the application logic is wired at client side and rendering is also done at the client side. And the simple reason for using Node is to have a full JavaScript stack.

Depends on what ur trying to build. But PayPal and LinkedIn has already switched over.
Primary reason is language is same for both front and back end.

Express.js is currently in lead (by far) as for framework.

Have fun!

No one  can't recommend or explain something that we doesn't know, i mean, we dont know the goal of  your app to recommend  something to you now, but if this  is your first time with node.js you should start with express.js.

If scaling, concurrency, and lightning-fast backend is your primary concern, have a look at Google's language, Go (http://golang.org/). Most people like nodejs for concurrency and consistency, and because they already know Javascript.
i would not start directly with express btw. that´s like starting with jquery before learning javascript. write your own little server before using one of those frameworks.
